sourceString: Phylogenetic evidence indicated that both HCoV-NL63 and HCoV-229E might have originated from bat CoVs, while the parental viruses of HCoV-OC43 and HCoV-HKU1 have been found in rodents.
targetString: Bilembeteli ya phylogenetique emonisi ete mbala mosusu HCoV-NL63 mpe HCoV-229E eutaki na ngembo CoVs, kasi bavirisi ya HCoV-OC43 mpe HCoV-HKU1 euta na ba rongeur.
en-mt: Phylogenetic evidence suggests that HCoV-NL63 and HCoV-229E probably originated from mosquito CoVs, whereas HCoV-OC43 and HCoV-HKU1 viruses originated from rodents.

sourceString: It has been reported that a bat CoV termed ARCoV.2 (Appalachian Ridge CoV) detected in North American tricolored bat displayed close relationship with HCoV-NL63.
targetString: Barapore emonisi ete ngembo ya CoV oyo babengi ARCoV.2 (Appalachian Ridge CoV) bamonaki yango na Amerika ya norde, mpe ngembo ya langi misato ezalaki na boyokani makasi na HCoV-NL63.
en-mt: Barapore notes that a CoV strain called ARCoV.2 (Appalachian Ridge CoV) was detected in North America, and the tricolor strain was closely related to HCoV-NL63.

sourceString: On the other hand, HCoV-229E was genetically related to another bat CoV, termed Hipposideros/GhanaKwam/19/2008, which was detected in Ghana, while camelids have also been suspected as its intermediate host.
targetString: Na ngambo mosusu, HCoV-229E ezalaka ndenge moko na CoV mosusu ya ngembo, oyo babengaki Hipposideros/GhanaKwam/19/2008, oyo bamonaki na Ghana, kasi balobaki ete esika na yango ya mibale ya kofanda ezalaki camelidés.
en-mt: Conversely, HCoV-229E is identical to another gecko CoV, designated Hipposideros/GhanaKwam/19/2008, which was detected in Ghana, but its secondary host was reported to be camelids.

sourceString: For clarity, the current knowledge on animal origins of known HCoVs is summarized in Figure ​1 and Table 2.
targetString: Mpo na koyeba malamu, boyebi ya sika ete HCoVs euta na banyama, bamonisi yango na mokuse na Motango​1 mpe Tablo 2.
en-mt: For clarity, the latest knowledge that HCoVs originate from animals is summarized in Figure 1 and Table

sourceString: Phylogenetic analysis has provided evidence for interspecies transmission events of HCoVs in the history.
targetString: Botaleli ya phylogenetique emonisi bilembeteli ete na lisolo na yango HCoVs euta na ekelamu moko mpe eleki na basusu.
en-mt: Phylogenetic analysis reveals evidence that historically HCoVs originate from one organism and are passed on to others.

sourceString: When HCoV-OC43 crossed species to infect humans from domestic livestock around 1890, a pandemic of respiratory infection was recorded.
targetString: Ntango HCoV-OC43 eutaka na ekelamu moko mpe eleki na mosusu mpo ekota na bato longwa na bibwele pene ya 1890, balobaki ebimisaki maladi moko ya mpema.
en-mt: When HCoV-OC43 originated from one organism and passed to another to enter humans from livestock around 1890, it was said to have caused a respiratory illness.

sourceString: The interspecies transmission history of HCoV-229E is less clear.
targetString: Lisolo oyo emonisi ndenge HCoV-229E eutaki na ekelamu moko mpe eleki na mosusu ezali polele te.
en-mt: The history of HCoV-229E transmission from one organism to another is unclear.

sourceString: Bat alpha-CoVs closely related to HCoV-229E have been found.
targetString: Basi bamona ete alpha-CoVs ya ngembo ezali na boyokani makasi na HCoV-229E.
en-mt: They found that alpha-CoVs of the goat are highly related to HCoV-229E.

sourceString: Between them there is an alpaca alpha-CoV.
targetString: Na kati na yango ezali na alpaca alpha-CoV moko.
en-mt: Among them is an alpaca alpha-CoV.

sourceString: Several lines of evidence support the transmission of virus from bats to humans directly.
targetString: Bilembetli mingi endimisi ete virisi wana eutaki na bangembo ebongo bapesaki yango mbala moko na bato.
en-mt: There is a lot of evidence that the virus came from bats and was immediately transmitted to humans.

sourceString: First, humans but not alpacas might have contact with bats in a shared ecological niche.
targetString: Ya liboso, bato kasi ba alpaca te nde ekutanaki na bangembo na esika oyo bafandaka.
en-mt: First, humans and not alpacas have been exposed to ticks in their natural habitat.

sourceString: Instead, humans have close contact with alpacas.
targetString: Atako bongo, bato bazali na boyokani ya pembeni mpenza na ba alpaca.
en-mt: Still, humans have a very close relationship with alpacas.

sourceString: Second, HCoV-229E-related bat alpha-CoVs are diverse and non-pathogenic in bats, whereas alpaca alpha-CoV caused an outbreak of respiratory disease in infected animals.
targetString: Ya mibale, HCoV-229E- euta na ngembo, alpha-CoVs ekeseni mpe epesaka maladi te na bangembo, kasi alpha-CoV alpaca ebimisaki maladi ya mpema na banyama oyo bazalaki na yango.
en-mt: Second, HCoV-229E- is derived from goats, alpha-CoVs are different and do not cause disease in goats, but alpha-CoV alpaca caused respiratory disease in infected animals.

sourceString: Finally, alpaca alpha-CoV has not been found in feral animals.
targetString: Na nsuka, alpha-CoV alpaca emonana te na nyei ya banyama.
en-mt: Finally, alpha-CoV alpaca was not detected in animal feces.

sourceString: Thus, the possibility cannot be excluded that alpacas obtain the HCoV-229E-related alpha-CoV from humans.
targetString: Yango wana, tokoki koboya te mbala moko ete ba alpaca bazwaki HCoV-229E ya alpha-CoV na bato.
en-mt: Therefore, we cannot simultaneously exclude that alpacas were infected with HCoV-229E of alpha-CoV in humans.

sourceString: In fact, bats are the direct source of human pathogenic viruses including rabies virus, Ebola virus, Nipah virus and Hendra virus.
targetString: Ya solo, bangembo bazali na ebandeli ya bavirisi mingi oyo ememela bato maladi, na ndakisa virisi ya bampuku, virisi ya Ebola, virisi Nipah mpe virisi Hendra.
en-mt: Indeed, mosquitoes are the source of many disease-causing viruses, such as mosquito virus, Ebola virus, Nipah virus, and Hendra virus.

sourceString: It is therefore not too surprising that bats might transmit HCoV-229E to humans directly.
targetString: Yango wana ezali kokamwisa te soki mbala mosusu bangembo nde bato bapesaki bato mbala moko virisi HCoV-229E.
en-mt: It is therefore not surprising that the HCoV-229E virus may have been directly transmitted to humans by mice.

sourceString: Alternatively, whereas bat alpha-CoVs serve as the gene pool of HCoV-229E, alpacas and dromedary camels might serve as intermediate hosts that transmit viruses to humans, exactly as in the case of MERS-CoV.
targetString: To, ata alpha-CoVs ngembo yango nde epesa makila na yango na CoV-229E, ba alpaca mpe bakamela dromadaire ekoki kozala esika ya mibale oyo efandaka oyo ememelaka bato bavirisi, kaka ndenge esalemaki mpo na MERS-CoV.
en-mt: Or, even if the alpha-CoVs donated their blood to CoV-229E, alpacas and dromadarian camels may be secondary habitats that transmit viruses to humans, as was the case with MERS-CoV.

sourceString: MERS-CoV serves as an excellent example of interspecies transmission from bats to dromedary camels and from dromedary camels to humans.
targetString: MERS-CoV ezali ndakisa ya malamu emonisa ndenge virisi eutaki na bangembo mpe ekomaka na bakamela dromadaire mpe longwa na bakamela dromadaire mpe ekotela bato.
en-mt: MERS-CoV is a good example of how the virus came from pigs to dromadaries and from dromadaries to humans.

sourceString: The evolutionary origin of MERS-CoV from bats is known at its initial identification and has also been strengthened by subsequent findings.
targetString: Bokoli ya esika MERS-CoV euta banda na bangembo eyebani ndenge bamonaki yango na ebandeli mpe makambo bamona nsima epusaka na kondima bango.
en-mt: The development of the source of MERS-CoV since the initial discovery of MERS-CoV is known and subsequent findings lead to their belief.

sourceString: It is obvious that bats provide a rich pool of virus species for interspecies exchange of genetic fragments and interspecies transmission.
targetString: Eyebani ete bangembo bazali na bavirisi mingi oyo ekabolamaka na kati ya bikelamu mingi mpe ndenge eutaka na ekelamu moko mpe ekotaka na ekelamu mosusu.
en-mt: Ticks are known to carry many viruses that are distributed among many organisms and that they are transmitted from one organism to another.

sourceString: Longevity, densely packed colonies, close social interaction and strong ability to fly are all favourable conditions for bats to be an ideal 'virus spreader'.
targetString: Kuwemela, kofanda bituluku moko, kozala na boyokani ya pene mpenza mpe makoki makasi ya kopumbwa ezali malamu mpenza mpo bangembo bazala ekelamu ya ‘kopanza virisi’.
en-mt: Fighting, living in groups, close relationships and strong flight abilities are ideal for ants to be 'virus-spreading' creatures.

sourceString: On the other hand, MERS-CoV has been introduced to dromedary camels for decades.
targetString: Na ngambo mosusu, MERS-CoV ekotela bakamela dromadaire banda kala.
en-mt: On the other hand, MERS-CoV has been infecting dromadarian camels for a long time.

sourceString: It is well adapted to these camels that have turned from an intermediate host to a stable and natural reservoir host.
targetString: Emesana mingi na bakamela wana yango wana ezalaka lisusu te esika na yango ya mibale ya kofanda kasi esika ebonga mpe ya malamu mpo na yango.
en-mt: It is so used to these camels that it is no longer its second home but a suitable and comfortable place for it.

sourceString: MERS-CoV causes very mild disease and maintains a relatively low mutation rate in these animals.
targetString: MERS-CoV ebimisaka maladi ya makasi te mpe epanzanaka mingi mpenza na kati ya banyama wana.
en-mt: MERS-CoV does not cause severe disease and is extremely widespread among these animals.

sourceString: Its sporadic transmission to humans is an accident and humans remain a dead-end host of MERS-CoV as its transmission cannot be sustained.
targetString: Ndenge ekota na bato ezali libaku mpe bato bakotikala kolata yango suka mpo kopanzana ya MERS-CoV ekoki kolanda te.
en-mt: The way it enters humans is an opportunity and people will continue to wear it eventually because the spread of MERS-CoV cannot continue.

sourceString: In contrast to the role of camels in the transmission of MERS-CoV, the role of pangolins, if there is any, in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2 is different.
targetString: Na kokesena na mokumba ya bakamela na kopanzana ya MERS-CoV, mokumba ya bapangolin, soki ekoki kozala, na kopanzana ya SARS-CoV-2 eza ya kokesena.
en-mt: Unlike the role of camels in the spread of MERS-CoV, the role of pangolins, if any, in the spread of SARS-CoV-2 is different.

sourceString: Particularly, pangolin beta-CoVs are highly pathogenic in pangolins.
targetString: Mingimingi, beta-CoVs pangolin epesaka maladi mingi na bapangolin.
en-mt: In particular, pangolin beta-CoVs are highly pathogenic in pangolins.

sourceString: They might be a dead-end host for SARS-CoV-2-related beta-CoVs, similar to civets in the case of SARS-CoV.
targetString: Bakozala esika ya liwa mpona SARS-CoV-2 mpe beta-CoVs, ndenge moko na ba civette mpo na SARS-CoV.
en-mt: They will be a deadly source for SARS-CoV-2 and beta-CoVs, just as civets are for SARS-CoV.

sourceString: Several possibilities for interspecies transmission of SARS-CoV-2 from animals to humans have to be ruled in or ruled out in future studies.
targetString: Ezali na makoki mingi mpo SARS-CoV-2 euta na ekelamu moko mpe ekota na mosusu, uta na banyama mpe ekotela bato, kasi ekosenga nde bolukiluki ya mikolo ezali koyaka nde endimisa yango.
en-mt: There is a high potential for SARS-CoV-2 to be transmitted from one organism to another, from animals to humans, but future research will need to confirm this.

sourceString: First, bats could be the reservoir host of a SARS-CoV-2-related virus almost identical to SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Ya liboso, bangembo ekoki kozala esika bavirisi SARS-CoV-2 efandaka oyo ekokani mpenza na SARS-CoV-2.
en-mt: First, mosquitoes may be home to SARS-CoV-2 viruses that closely resemble SARS-CoV-2.

sourceString: Humans might share the ecological niche with bats through butchering or coal mining.
targetString: Bato bakoki kokabola esika moko elongo na bangembo na nzela ya koboma bango to na mine ya makala.
en-mt: People can share a place with the bangers by killing them or in a coal mine.

sourceString: Second, pangolins could be one of intermediate amplifying host to which a SARS-CoV-2-related virus had been newly introduced.
targetString: Liboso, ba pangolin bakoki kozala moko ya bisika ya mibale ya malamu oyo virisi SARS-CoV-2 ekota kala te.
en-mt: First, pangolins may be one of the second best sites for the recent entry of the SARS-CoV-2 virus.

sourceString: Humans contract the virus through butchering and consumption of game meat.
targetString: Bato bazwaka virisi na nzela ya koboma banyama mpe kolya mosuni ya banyama.
en-mt: Humans contract the virus through slaughter and consumption of animal meat.

sourceString: It is possible that many mammals including domestic animals are susceptible to SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Ekoki kozala ete banyama babengami bamamifere ata banyama efandaka na ndako ekoki kozwa SARS-CoV-2.
en-mt: It is possible that mammals and even domestic animals can contract SARS-CoV-2

sourceString: A survey of domestic and wild animals for antibodies is warranted.
targetString: Bolukiluki na banyama ya ndako mpe ya zamba mpo na kosala ba anticorps ebongi mpenza.
en-mt: Research in domestic and wild animals to develop antibodies is particularly appropriate.

sourceString: Third, as mentioned above, recombination and adaptation of SARS-CoV-2 might have occurred in a third species that has contact with both bats and pangolins.
targetString: Ya misato, ndenge tolobeli likolo, kosangisa lisusu mpe komesana ya SARS-CoV-2 mbala mosusu esalemaki na ekelamu ya misato oyo ekutanaki na bangembo mpe bapangolin.
en-mt: Third, as discussed above, recombination and adaptation of SARS-CoV-2 likely occurred in a third organism that contacted baboons and pangolins.

sourceString: The search for the animal origins of SARS-CoV-2 is still on.
targetString: Bazali kosala bolukiluki mpo na koyeba esika SARS-CoV-2 euta.
en-mt: The source of SARS-CoV-2 is being investigated.

sourceString: Apart from different types of the animal hosts, three major factors on the viral side are also important in facilitating CoVs to cross species barriers.
targetString: Longola balolenge wana ya banyama oyo ekoki kozala na yango, makambo misato ya minene etali virisi oyo eza mpe ntina mingi mpo na kosalisa CoVs ezali kokota na bikelamu mosusu.
en-mt: In addition to these potential animal species, three major aspects of the virus that is also important for the treatment of CoVs are the infection of other organisms.

sourceString: First of all, their relatively high mutation rates in RNA replication.
targetString: Ya liboso, ndenge etambolaka mingi na RNA mpe ebotaka.
en-mt: First, how it travels a lot with RNA and reproduces.

sourceString: In comparison to other single-stranded RNA viruses, the estimated mutation rates of CoVs could be regarded as “moderate” to “high” with an average substitution rate being ~10-4 substitution per year per site 2, depending on the phase of CoV adaptation to novel hosts.
targetString: Na bokeseni na bavirisi mosusu ya RNA, ndenge CoVs etambolaka ekoki kotalelama neti “ya malamu” mpe “ya makasi” mpe echangaka na ~10-4 na mbula moko na bisika 2, na kotalela lolenge ya CoV ndenge ezali komesana na bisika na yango ya sika.
en-mt: Unlike other RNA viruses, the movement of CoVs can be considered “normal” and “robust” and changes at ~10-4 times per year in 2 environments, depending on the type of CoV as it adapts to its environment money.

sourceString: CoVs have a proof-reading exoribonuclease, deletion of which results in exceedingly high mutability and attenuation or even inviability.
targetString: CoVs ezali na botangi moko ya exoribonuclease, koboma yango ekoki kosala ete ebotama lisusu mingi mpenza mpe kokitisa bokasi na yango to nkutu ekoka kokola te.
en-mt: CoVs have a single exoribonuclease reading, killing them can cause them to reproduce dramatically and reduce their effectiveness or even fail to grow.

sourceString: Interestingly, the nucleotide analogue Remdesivir is known to suppress CoV replication through inhibition of this exoribonuclease and the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.
targetString: Likambo ezali kobenda likebi ezali ete eyebani ete nucleotide ya ntina ya Remdesivir ebomaka kobotama ya CoV ndenge ekangaka exoribonuclease oyo mpe RNA oyo eutaka na polymerase RNA.
en-mt: Interestingly, the core nucleotide of Remdesivir is known to kill CoV replication as it blocks this exoribonuclease and RNA from RNA polymerase.

sourceString: Remdesivir is one of most promising anti-SARS-CoV-2 agents to be tested in clinical trials.
targetString: Remdesivir eza moko ya bankisi ya malamu mingi ya SARS-CoV-2 oyo esengeli bameka yango na bato.
en-mt: Remdesivir is one of the most effective SARS-CoV-2 drugs that needs to be tested in humans.

sourceString: Nevertheless, mutation rates of CoVs are about a million times higher than those of their hosts.
targetString: Atako bongo, motango ya mutation ya CoVs ezali likolo pene ya milio moko koleka ya bisika oyo efandaka.
en-mt: Nevertheless, the mutation rate of CoVs is higher by about one million than the habitats.

sourceString: In addition, mutation rate is often high when CoVs are not well adapted to the host.
targetString: Lisusu, mbala mingi motango ya mutation ezalaki mingi soki CoVs emesani te na esika na yango ya sika.
en-mt: Moreover, the mutation rate was usually higher if CoVs were not adapted to their new environment.

sourceString: Compared to SARS-CoV with a high mutation rate, the mutation rate of SARS-CoV-2 is apparently lower, suggestive of a higher level of adaptation to humans.
targetString: Soki tokokanisi yango na SARS-CoV oyo ezali na motango ya mutation ya likolo, emonani ete motango ya mutation ya SARS-CoV-2 ezali na nse, oyo ezali komonisa ete emesanaka mingi mpenza na bato.
en-mt: Compared to SARS-CoV with a higher mutation rate, SARS-CoV-2 appears to have a lower mutation rate, indicating that it adapts significantly more to humans.

sourceString: Presumably, it has already been adapted to another host close to humans.
targetString: Tokoki koloba ete, esi emesana na esika mosusu ya kofanda oyo ezli pene na bato.
en-mt: In a sense, it has adapted to another settlement that is close to people.

sourceString: In addition to SARS-CoV-2, this also applies to MERS-CoV, which is well adapted to dromedary camels.
targetString: Longola SARS-CoV-2, etali mpe MERS-CoV, oyo emesana malamu na bakamela dromadaire.
en-mt: In addition to SARS-CoV-2, it also applies to MERS-CoV, which is well adapted to dromadarian camels.

sourceString: Theoretically, it is unlikely that genetic drift would render vaccines and antivirals against SARS-CoV-2 ineffective quickly.
targetString: Na maloba, ezali mpo mbongwana ya genotype ekobimisa mangwele mpe bankisi ya kobundisa virisi SARS-CoV-2 mpo noki ezala makasi te.
en-mt: In words, it is because the genotype change will produce vaccines and anti-SARS-CoV-2 virus drugs so that it soon becomes weaker.

sourceString: Second, the large RNA genome in CoVs exerts extra plasticity in genome modification for mutations and recombination, thereby increasing the probability for interspecies co-evolution, which is advantageous for the emergence of novel CoVs when the conditions become appropriate.
targetString: Ya mibale, genome RNA ya monene oyo ezali na CoVs ezala na mwa bopusi na mbongwana oyo esalemaka mpe na bozongi na yango, yango wana ematisaka makoki na yango ya kokola, mpe ezali malamu mpo na kobima ya CoVs ya sika ntango makambo ekobonga.
en-mt: Second, the large RNA genome containing CoVs is relatively sensitive to mutations and replication, thus increasing their ability to evolve, and is conducive to the emergence of new CoVs when conditions improve.

sourceString: This is supported by the copious unique open reading frames and protein functions encoded towards the 3′ end of the genome.
targetString: Likambo oyo esimbami na ndenge bakadre na yango efungwamaka mpe mosala ya proteine ebimisaka 3’ nsuka ya genome.
en-mt: This fact is underpinned by the fact that its frames open and the activity of the protein releases the 3' end of the genome.

sourceString: Third, CoVs randomly and frequently switch templates during RNA replication through a unique “copy-choice” mechanism.
targetString: Ya misato, CoVs ebongolaka ndenge na yango kaka boye mpe mbala mingi ntango ebongolaka RNA na nzela ya mayele ya kokamwa ya “kopona-kopi”.
en-mt: Third, CoVs change shape just so and often when modifying RNA through a remarkable “selective-copy” mechanism.

sourceString: In a host that serves as the mixing vessel, strand switching occurs frequently during CoV RNA transcription.
targetString: Na esika oyo efandaka mpe oyo esalaka na kosangisa yango, ebongwanaka mbala mingi na ntango ya kokoma CoV RNA.
en-mt: In the environment in which it resides and in which it interacts, it changes several times during CoV RNA transcription.

sourceString: Highly homologous full-length and subgenomic RNAs could recombine to generate new CoVs.
targetString: Ba RNAs ya milai mingi ya ndenge moko mpe ba genome ya mike ekoki kosangana mpo na kobimisa CoVs ya sika.
en-mt: Very long similar RNAs and small genomes can combine to produce novel CoVs.

sourceString: Phylogenetic evidence of natural recombination has been found in both HCoV-HKU1 and HCoV-OC43, as well as animal CoVs such as bat SL-CoV and batCoV-HKU9.
targetString: Bilembeteli ya phylogenetique ya kosangana ya normal emonanaki na HCoV-HKU1 mpe HCoV-OC43, mpe na CoVs nyama na ndakisa SL-CoV ngembo mpe batCoV-HKU9.
en-mt: Phylogenetic evidence of normal mixing was observed in HCoV-HKU1 and HCoV-OC43, and in animal CoVs such as SL-CoV ngambo and batCoV-HKU9.

sourceString: Virus-host interaction in relation to transmission
targetString: Boyakani ya virisi na esika virisi efandaka na oyo etali ndenge epanzanaka
en-mt: The relationship of the virus to the viral environment in terms of how it spreads

sourceString: Besides three viral factors stated above, viral interaction with host receptor is another key factor influential on interspecies transmission.
targetString: Longola makambo misato ya virisi oyo tolobeli na likolo, boyokani ya virisi na esika efandaka ezali eloko mosusu ya ntina na oyo etali ndenge eutaka na bikelamu moko mpe ekota na ekelamu mosusu.
en-mt: In addition to the three aspects of the virus mentioned above, the relationship of the virus to its habitat is another important factor in its transmission from one organism to another.

sourceString: Herein, recombination of SARS-CoV is taken as a typical example, which also showed evidence of positive selection during interspecies transmission events.
targetString: Na kati, kosangana ya SARS-CoV elobelami neti ndakisa, mpe emonisi ete epanzaka maladi ntangu ekutaka na ekelamu moko mpe ekotaka na ekelamu mosusu.
en-mt: In it, the SARS-CoV combination is discussed as an example, and shows that it spreads disease when it meets one organism and enters another.

sourceString: Based on the comparative analysis between isolates of human and civet SARS-CoVs, SARS-CoV is thought to undergo rapid adaptation in different hosts, particularly with mutations at the RBD of the S protein.
targetString: Na kolanda botaleli ya kokesenisa na kati ya bato mpe nyama civet SARS-CoVs, emonani ete SARS-CoV ekokoba kobongwana noki na bisika oyo efandaka, mingimingi ndenge etambolaka na RBD ya proteine S.
en-mt: Based on the comparative analysis of human and civet SARS-CoVs, it appears that SARS-CoV will continue to evolve rapidly in its habitats, particularly as it moves with the S protein RBD.

sourceString: Generally, the RBD in the S protein of a CoV interacts with the cellular receptor and is intensely selected by the host antibody response.
targetString: Mbala mingi, RBD ya proteine S ya CoV ezalaka na boyokani na baselile oyo ezwaka yango mpe eponamaka mingi na anticorp ya esika ekei kofanda.
en-mt: The RBD of the CoV S protein is usually associated with host cells and is highly selective for the host antibody.

sourceString: In SARS-CoV, the RBD is in the 318th to 510th amino acids on the S1 fragment, which binds to the human ACE2 as well as its coreceptors for viral entry.
targetString: Na SARS-CoV, RBD ezali na aside amino ya 318 kino ya 510 na eteni ya S1 , oyo esanganaka na ACE2 ya bato mpe bisika mosusu oyo virisi ekotaka.
en-mt: In SARS-CoV, the RBD consists of amino acids 318 to 510 in the S1 segment , which associates with human ACE2 and other viral entry sites.

sourceString: The RBD of SARS-CoV is capable of recognizing the ACE2 receptors of various animals, including bat, civet, mouse and raccoon dog, allowing interspecies transmission of the virus.
targetString: RBD ya SARS-CoV ekoki koyeba bikoko ezwaka ACE2 ya banyama mingi, na ndakisa ngembo, civet, mpuku mpe mbwa ya zamba, yango esalisaka virisi euta na ekelamu moko mpe ekota na ekelamu mosusu.
en-mt: The RBD of SARS-CoV can be detected by chickens that infect the ACE2 of many animals, such as foxes, civets, foxes and wild dogs, which allows the virus to move from one organism to another.

sourceString: In fact, only 6 amino acid residues were observed to be different from human and civet viral isolates in the RBD and 4 of them locate in the receptor-binding motif for interaction with the ACE2 receptor.
targetString: Ya solo, batika ya ba-amino aside 6 mpamba emonanaki ete ekeseni na bato mpe virisi ya civet oyo babimisaki na RBD mpe 4 kati na yango oyo ezali na eloko ezwaka yango ezalaka na boyokani na eloko ezwaka ACE2.
en-mt: Indeed, only 6 amino acid residues were found to be different from human and RBD-produced civet viruses and 4 of these receptor-bearing ones are associated with the ACE2 receptor.

sourceString: Civet SARS-CoV has K479N and S487T mutations in its RBD, which might increase the affinity of the interaction of spike protein with human ACE2 receptor.
targetString: SARS-CoV civet ezali na mbongwana ya K479N mpe ya S487T na RBD na yango, mpe yango ematisaka boyakani kati ya proteine ya nsonge na ACE2 ya bato oyo ezwaka yango.
en-mt: SARS-CoV civet contains both the K479N and the S487T changes in its RBD, and this enhances the interaction between the peak protein and the ACE2 of human hosts.

sourceString: In other words, these two amino acid substitutions might be critical to viral adaption to humans.
targetString: Na maloba mosusu, biloko mibale oyo ezwaka esika ya aside amino ekoki kozala ntina mingi mpo virisi emesana na nzoto ya bato.
en-mt: In other words, two amino acid substitutions may be essential for the virus to adapt to the human body.

sourceString: It is noteworthy that SARS-CoV-2 shares the same cellular receptor with SARS-CoV.
targetString: Eza ntina koyeba ete SARS-CoV-2 eza ya ndenge moko oyo ebombaka yango neti SARS-CoV.
en-mt: It is important to note that SARS-CoV-2 is a strain that hides itself as SARS-CoV.

sourceString: A 30% difference between SARS-CoV-2 and SARS-CoV in the S1 unit of the S protein implicates that the binding affinity of its S protein with human ACE2 might have altered.
targetString: Bokeseni ya 30% na kati ya SARS-CoV-2 mpe SARS-CoV na eteni S1 ya proteine S emonisi ete boyokani ya proteine S na yango na ACE2 ya bato ekoki kobongwana.
en-mt: The 30% difference between SARS-CoV-2 and SARS-CoV in the S1 portion of the S protein suggests that the interaction of its S protein with human ACE2 may be altered.

sourceString: Indeed, a cryo-EM study indicates a 10- to 20-fold higher affinity of this binding than that between human ACE2 and SARS-CoV S protein.
targetString: Ya solo, bolukiluki moko ya cryo-EM emonisi ete boyokani ya 10- kino 20- ya bosangani oyo koleka oyo eza kati ya ACE2 ya bato mpe SARS-CoV ya proteine S.
en-mt: Indeed, a cryo-EM study suggests a 10- to 20-fold greater affinity for this interaction than that between human ACE2 and S-protein SARS-CoV.

sourceString: It will also be of interest to determine whether any other coreceptor might be required for SARS-CoV-2 transmission.
targetString: Ekozala mpe ntina na koyeba soki ekosenga eloko mosusu mpo na kopanza SARS-CoV-2.
en-mt: It will also be important to determine whether something else will be needed to spread SARS-CoV-2

sourceString: Intriguingly, HCoV-NL63 also binds to ACE2 but with a different part of S.
targetString: Likambo ezokamwisa, HCoV-NL63 esanganaka mpe na ACE2 kasi na eteni mosusu ya S.
en-mt: Interestingly, HCoV-NL63 also associates with ACE2 but with a different S component.

sourceString: There exist many other HCoV receptors, such as aminopeptidase N for HCoV-229E, and 9-O-acetylated sialic acid for HCoV-OC43.
targetString: Ezali na biloko mingi mosusu oyo eyambaka HCoV, na ndakisa aminopeptidase N mpo na HCoV-229E, mpe 9-O-aside sialique acetylé mpo na HCoV-OC43.
en-mt: There are many other HCoV receptors, including aminopeptidase N for HCoV-229E, and acetylated 9-O-sialic acid for HCoV-OC43.

sourceString: They might also account for successful adaptation of these CoVs in humans after interspecies transmission from their animal hosts.
targetString: Ekoki mpe kosalisa na ndenge ba CoVs oyo ekokaka komesana na nzoto ya bato nsima ya kouta na banyama esika ezalaka.
en-mt: It may also help with the ability of these CoVs to adapt to the human body after originating from animals.

sourceString: In addition to cellular receptors, the outcome of interspecies transmission of HCoVs is also governed by other host dependency and restriction factors.
targetString: Longola baselila oyo eyambaka yango, matomba ya ndenge HCoVs eutaka ekelamu moko mpe ekotaka na ekelamu mosusu etambwisami na boyokani na yango na bisika mosusu oyo efandaka mpe makambo oyo ekangaka yango nzela.
en-mt: In addition to host cells, the effects of how HCoVs move from one organism to another are governed by their interactions with other habitats and barriers.

sourceString: The divergence of these host proteins between humans and natural reservoir hosts of HCoVs such as bats, dromedary camels and rodents might constitute a barrier to interspecies transmission.
targetString: Bokeseni ya baproteine ya bisika oyo efandaka na kati ya bato mpe esika oyo biloko oyo ebombaka HCoVs ezalaka na ndakisa bangembo, bakamela dromadaire mpe ba rongeur ekoki kozala eloko oyo ekopekisa yango euta ne ekelamu moko mpe ekota na mosusu.
en-mt: Protein diversity of habitats among humans and the location of reservoirs of HCoVs such as geese, dromadarian camels and rodents may be a barrier to transmission from ne one organism to another.

sourceString: HCoVs have to usurp host dependency factors and subvert host restriction factors for a successful interspecies transmission.
targetString: HCoVs esengeli kozwa ya esika ya eloko ebomaka yango mpe kobongola makambo oyo ekangaka yango nzela mpo ezwa likoki ya kouta na ekelamu moko mpe kokota na ekelamu mosusu.
en-mt: HCoVs must acquire of the environment that kills it and change the factors that prevent it from being able to move from one organism to another.

sourceString: In this regard, molecular determinants in this important area of virus-host interaction remain to be identified and characterized.
targetString: Na likambo oyo, eloko esalisaka na koyeba molekile na likambo ya ntina oyo etali boyokani na kati ya virisi mpe esika efandaka eyebani kaka te mpe ekosenga kolukaluka.
en-mt: In this case, the contribution of molecular identification to the important issue of interactions in the virus and its environment is still unknown and will require investigation.

sourceString: An unbiased genome-wide screening of host dependency and restriction factors for SARS-CoV-2 using the state-of-the-art technology of CRISPR might be fruitful.
targetString: Depistage ya malamu ya dependance ya genome mpe makambo oyo ekangaka yango nzela mpo na SARS-CoV-2 oyo esalelaka mayele makasi ya CRISPR ekoki kosalisa.
en-mt: Better screening of genome dependence and constraining factors for SARS-CoV-2 using strong CRISPR technology may help.

sourceString: Emergence of novel HCoVs: back to ground zero
targetString: Kobima ya HCoVs ya sika: kozonga na ebandeli
en-mt: Emergence of new HCoVs: back to the beginning

sourceString: The diversity of bat CoVs provides ample opportunities for the emergence of novel HCoVs.
targetString: Bokeseni ya CoVs ngembo ezali kopesa makambo mingi mpo na kobima ya HCoVs ya sika.
en-mt: The diversity of CoVs in the field provides many factors for the emergence of new HCoVs.

sourceString: In this sense, bat CoVs serve as the gene pool of HCoVs.
targetString: Na ndimbola, CoVs ngembo ezali esika oyo HCoVs eutaka.
en-mt: By definition, CoVs ngambo is the source of HCoVs.

sourceString: In addition, rapid mutation and genetic recombination also drive HCoV evolution and serve as two important steps in this process.
targetString: Lisusu, mutation ya noki mpe kosangana ya ba gene esalisaka mpe na bokoli ya HCoV mpe ezalaka bitambe mibale ya ntina na likambo oyo.
en-mt: Moreover, rapid mutation and gene integration also contribute to HCoV progression and are two important steps in this process.

sourceString: For example, the acquisition or loss of novel protein-coding genes has the potential to drastically modify viral phenotypes.
targetString: Na ndakisa, kozwa to kobungisa codage ya ba gene ya proteine ezali na likoki ya kobongola mingi mpenza boyokani na kati ya bavirisi.
en-mt: For example, gain or loss of protein gene coding has the potential to dramatically alter interactions within viruses.

sourceString: Among SARS-CoV accessory proteins, ORF8 has been thought to be important in adaptation to humans, as SARS-CoV-related bat viruses were isolated but found to encode divergent ORF8 proteins.
targetString: Na kati ya biloko ya baproteine SARS-CoV, emonani ete ORF8 eza ntina mingi mpo emesana na nzoto ya bato, mpo bavirisi ya ngembo ya SARS-CoV, batyaki yango mopanzi kasi emonanaki ezalaka lolenge mosusu ya kobombana ya baproteine ORF8.
en-mt: Among the SARS-CoV proteins, ORF8 appears to be the most important for adaptation to the human body, because SARS-CoV anthrax viruses, have been set aside but have been found to be another latent form of ORF8 proteins.

sourceString: A 29-nucleotide deletion characteristic of SARS-CoVs has been found in strains isolated at the beginning of the human epidemic.
targetString: Bamonaki ete babomaki 29-nucleotide ya SARS-CoVs oyo batyaka na mopanzi na ebandeli ya maladi mabe epai ya bato.
en-mt: They found that the 29-nucleotide flanker of SARS-CoVs was killed at the onset of malignancy in humans.

sourceString: This deletion splits ORF8 into ORF8a and ORF8b and is thought to be an adaptive mutation that promotes the switch of hosts.
targetString: Koboma oyo ekabola ORF8 na ORF8a mpe ORF8b mpe bakanisi eza eloko oyo esalisaka yango elongwa na esika mpe ekota na bisika mosusu.
en-mt: This kill separates ORF8 from ORF8a and ORF8b and is thought to be what helps it move from one site to another.

sourceString: Besides, SARS-CoV has a possible recombination history with lineages of alpha- and gamma-CoVs, where a large number of smaller recombinant regions were identified in the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.
targetString: Lisusu, SARS-CoV ekoki kosangana lisusu na molongo ya alpha- mpe gamma-CoVs, esika bosangani mingi ya mikemike emonanaki na RNA oyo euta na RNA ya polymerase.
en-mt: Furthermore, SARS-CoV can recombine with the alpha- and gamma-CoVs sequence, where many minor combinations have been observed with RNA from RNA polymerase.

sourceString: Recombination locations were also identified in the nsp9, most of nsp10, and parts of nsp14.
targetString: Bisika ya kosangisa yango emonanaki mpe na nsp9, mingi ya nsp10, mpe biteni ya nsp14.
en-mt: Sites of this fusion were also observed in nsp9, most of nsp10, and fragments of nsp14.

sourceString: Likewise, it has been shown that the epidemic MERS-CoV experienced recombination events between different lineages, which occurred in dromedary camels in Saudi Arabia.
targetString: Ndenge moko, emonani ete maladi mabe ya MERS-CoV esanganaki na kati ya milongo mingi, oyo esalemaki na bakamela dromadaire ya Arabie Saudite.
en-mt: Similarly, MERS-CoV malignancies appear to have been associated in several lines, which were carried out in Saudi Arabian dromadarian camels.

sourceString: Besides SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV, recombination events have also been observed in other HCoVs, in which the HCoVs recombine with other animal CoVs in their non-structural genes.
targetString: Longola SARS-CoV mpe MERS-CoV, makambo ya kosangana emonanaki mpe na ba HCoVs mosusu, na kati na yango HCoVs esanganaki na CoVs ya nyama mosusu na ba gene na yango.
en-mt: In addition to SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV, fusion events have also been observed in other HCoVs, in which HCoVs have fused with other animal CoVs in their genes.

sourceString: It should also be cautioned that artificial selection can contribute to unintended changes in viral genomes, most likely resulting from relieving viruses from selection pressures exerted, such as by the host immune system.
targetString: Esengeli mpe kokeba mpo kopona oyo ya lokuta ekoki komema na mbongwana tokanaki te ya ba genome oyo ememaka bavirisi, mpe ekoki ete elembisa bavirisi na bopusi oyo ezali kokutana na yango, na ndakisa mikrobe oyo ebundisaka maladi na nzoto ya bato oyo bazalo na yango.
en-mt: Care must also be taken because spurious selection may lead to unintended changes in viral vector genomes, and may weaken viruses against the influences they face, such as host immune responses.

sourceString: An example of these effects is the loss of a full-length ORF4 in the HCoV-229E prototype strain, owing to a two-nucleotide deletion.
targetString: Na ndakisa moko ya makambo wana ezali kobungisa mobimba ya ORF4 na HCoV-229E prototype, oyo esalemaki mpo babomaki ba nucleotide mibale.
en-mt: For example one of these features is the complete loss of ORF4 in the HCoV-229E prototype, which occurred because two nucleotides were killed.

sourceString: While intact ORF4 could be observed in bat and camel viruses related to HCoV-229E, the alpaca alpha-CoV displays a single nucleotide insertion, resulting in a frameshift.
targetString: Ata ORF4 oyo ebebi te ekoki komonana na ngembo mpe na bavirisi ya bakamela oyo ezali na boyokani na HCoV-229E, alpha-CoV alpaca emonisaki kobakisama ya nucleotide moko, esalaki ete kadre ebongwana.
en-mt: Although an intact ORF4 can be observed in geese and HCoV-229E-related camel viruses, alpha-CoV alpaca exhibited a single nucleotide amplification, causing a frame shift.

sourceString: Last but not least, the evolution of novel HCoVs is also driven by the selection pressure in their reservoir hosts.
targetString: Ya nsuka kasi ya ntina, kokola ya HCoVs ya sika euti na bopusi ezali na bisika efandaka.
en-mt: Last but not least, the development of new HCoVs results from the impact it has on habitats.

sourceString: Asymptomatic or only mild symptoms were detected when bats were infected with CoVs, indicating the mutual adaptation between CoVs and bats.
targetString: Kozanga bilembo to kozala na bilembo kaka moke emonanaki ntango bangembo bazwaki CoVs, yango emonisi komesana na kati ya CoVs mpe bangembo.
en-mt: No symptoms or only minimal symptoms were observed when ticks were exposed to CoVs, indicating adaptation among CoVs and ticks.

sourceString: It appeared that bats are well adapted to CoVs anatomically and physiologically.
targetString: Emonani ete bangembo emeseni mpenza na CoVs na makambo ya anatomie mpe ya physiologie.
en-mt: It appears that bats are quite anatomically and physiologically adapted to CoVs.

sourceString: For example, defects in the activation of pro-inflammatory response in bats efficiently reduce the pathology triggered by CoVs.
targetString: Na ndakisa, bambeba na kobimisa mukusa malamumalamu na bangembo ekitisaki maladi oyo CoVs ekoki kobimisa.
en-mt: For example, deficiencies in the proper removal of mushrooms from insects have reduced the disease that CoVs can cause.

sourceString: Besides, the natural killer cell activity in bats is suppressed due to upregulation of inhibitory natural killer cell receptor NKG2/CD94 and low expression level of major histocompatibility complex class I molecules.
targetString: Lisusu, selile oyo ebomaka bangembo ekufaki mpo bamatisaki selile oyo ebomaka yango mpenza NKG2/CD94 mpe emonisaki nivo ya nse ya histocompatibilié ya makasi ya mindondomindondo ya bamolecule ya kelasi I.
en-mt: Moreover, the germ cell died because the specific killer cell NKG2/CD94 was upregulated and showed low levels of complex histocompatibility of class I molecules.

sourceString: Moreover, the high level of reactive oxygen species (ROS) generated from high metabolic activity of bats could both suppress CoV replication and affects proofreading by exoribonuclease, thus providing the selection pressure for the generation of virus strains highly pathogenic when introduced into a new host.
targetString: Lisusu, nivo ya makasi ya bandakisa ya oxygene (ROS) oyo eutaka na metabolisme makasi ya bangembo ekoki koboma CoV to ebotama mpe kozala na bopusi na botangi na yango na nzela ya exoribonuclease, yango wana esalisaka na kopona bopusi ya bavirisi oyo epesaka mpenza maladi soki ekoki na esika ya sika.
en-mt: Furthermore, high levels of reactive oxygen species (ROS) resulting from the intense metabolism of guinea pigs can kill CoV or be reproduced and affect its processing by exoribonuclease, thus helping to selectively affect truly pathogenic viruses if enough in a new location.

sourceString: More pathogenic CoV strains might also evolve by recombination, leading to the acquisition of novel proteins or protein features for host adaptation.
targetString: Maladi mingi ya CoV ekoki mpe kokola na nzela ya kosangana, ekomema na kozwa baproteine ya sika to baproteine mpo na komesana na esika ya efandi.
en-mt: Many CoV diseases can also evolve by mating, leading to the acquisition of new proteins or proteins to adapt to the environment.

sourceString: Thus, it is not by chance that three novel HCoVs have emerged in the past two decades.
targetString: Yango wana, eza te kaka chance ndenge ba HCoVs misato ya sika ebimaki na bambula ntuku mibale oyo eleki.
en-mt: Therefore, it’s not just chance that three new HCoVs have emerged in the past two decades.

sourceString: CoVs are non-pathogenic or cause mild symptoms in their reservoir hosts such as bats and camels.
targetString: CoVs epeska te maladi to ebimisaka te bilembo ya mike na bisika efandaka na ndakisa na bangembo mpe na bakamela.
en-mt: CoVs do not cause disease or cause minor symptoms in habitats such as goats and camels.

sourceString: They replicate robustly without eliciting a strong host immune response.
targetString: Ebotamaka mingi kozanga kosalela mikrobe ebundisaka maladi ya moto oyo aza na yango.
en-mt: It is often reproduced without the use of bacteria that fight the disease of the infected person.

sourceString: Herein lie the secrets of why asymptomatic carriers are seen and what causes the severe cases in human infection.
targetString: Awa nde esika baseleke ya koyeba soki bato oyo bazali na bilembo te bamonana mpe oyo esalaka ete ebelisa bato makasi mpenza.
en-mt: This is where the secrets of asymptomatic detection lie and what makes it so infectious.

sourceString: The severe symptoms are mainly due to the hyperactivation of immune response and the cytokine storm wherein the stronger the immune response, the more severe the lung damage.
targetString: Bilembo ya makasi euti mingimingi na hyperactivation ya mikrobe oyo ebundisaka maladi mpe ba cytokine mingi na esika mikrobe oyo ebundisaka maladi ezalaka makasi, mpe yango ebebisaka poumon mingi.
en-mt: Severe symptoms are mainly due to hyperactivation of the immune system and high levels of cytokines in a strong immune environment, resulting in extensive lung damage.

sourceString: In contrast, in asymptomatic carriers, the immune response has been de-coupled from CoV replication.
targetString: Na kokesena, na bato ya maladi oyo bazali na bilembo te, mikrobe oyo ebundisaka maladi oyo euti na kobotama ya CoV esalaka mbala mibale.
en-mt: In contrast, in asymptomatic patients, the immune response resulting from CoV replication is doubly effective.

sourceString: The same strategy of delinking the immune response might have beneficial effects in anti-SARS-CoV-2 therapy.
targetString: Mayele ya lolenge moko kolongola mikrobe oyo ebundisaka maladi ekoki kozala na bopusi malamu na nkisi ya SARS-CoV-2.
en-mt: Similar strategies removing the immune system may have a positive impact on the treatment of SARS-CoV-2.

sourceString: The interferon response is particularly strong in bats.
targetString: Interferon esalaka makasi mpenza mingimingi na bangembo.
en-mt: Interferon is especially effective in infections.

sourceString: Thus, administration of type I interferon at least in the early phase of SARS-CoV-2 infection in humans should be beneficial.
targetString: Yango wana, kopesa interferon ya lolenge I ata kaka na ebandeli ya maladi ya SARS-CoV-2 na nzoto ya bato esengeli esalisa mingi.
en-mt: Therefore, delivery of type I interferon at least at the very beginning of SARS-CoV-2 infection in humans should be very helpful.

sourceString: In addition, NLRP3 inflammasome activation in bats is defective.
targetString: Lisusu, koningisa NLRP3 na inflammasome na bangembo esimbaka te.
en-mt: Furthermore, shaking NLRP3 with the inflammasome in monkeys does not work.

sourceString: By this reasoning, inhibition of NLRP3 inflammasome with MCC950 might be useful in the treatment of COVID-19.
targetString: Na kotalela makanisi oyo, koningisa NLRP3 na inflammasome elongo na MCC950 ekoki kosalisa na kozwa nkisi ya COVID-19.
en-mt: Based on these considerations, immobilization of NLRP3 to the inflammasome together with MCC950 may aid in COVID-19 therapy.

sourceString: The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 follows the general theme by which SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV arose.
targetString: Kobima ya SARS-CoV-2 ezali kolanda moto ya likambo moko oyo esalaka ete SARS-CoV mpe MERS-CoV ebima.
en-mt: The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 follows the fire of the same event that causes the emergence of SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV.

sourceString: Whereas a bat beta-CoV sharing 95% nucleotide homology with SARS-CoV has been found, there also exists a bat-CoV sharing 96% nucleotide homology with SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Ata emonana ete beta-CoV ya ngembo ezali na 95% ya nucleotide ya ndenge moko na SARS-CoV, bat-CoV ezali na 96% ya ba nucleotide ya ndenge moko na SARS-CoV-2.
en-mt: Although it was found that the beta-CoV of the goat has 95% nucleotide identity to SARS-CoV, the bat-CoV has 96% nucleotide identity to SARS-CoV-2

sourceString: Whereas civets and other animals in the markets have been found to harbour viruses identical to SARS-CoV, immediate intermediate hosts for SARS-CoV-2 have not been identified.
targetString: Ata emonanaki ete ba civet mpe banyama mosusu na bazando ezali na bavirisi ya lolenge moko na SARS-CoV, bisika ya sika oyo SARS-CoV-2 ekendaka kofanda ezali ndenge moko.
en-mt: Even though civets and other market animals have been found to carry viruses of the same type as SARS-CoV, the new migrations of SARS-CoV-2 are similar.

sourceString: Pangolin beta-CoVs strikingly homologous to SARS-CoV-2 have been found, indicating that pangolins might serve as one of intermediate hosts or pangolin beta-CoVs could contribute gene fragments to the final version of SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Emonani ete beta-CoVs ya pangolin ekokani mingi mpenza na SARS-CoV-2, emonisi ete bapangolin bakoki kozala esika moko oyo bavirisi wana efandaka to beta-CoVs ya bapangolin esalisaka na kokabola ba gene ya nsuka ya SARS-CoV-2.
en-mt: It appears that pangolin beta-CoVs are very similar to SARS-CoV-2, suggesting that pangolins may be a common host for these viruses or that pangolin beta-CoVs contribute to final gene distribution of SARS-CoV-2.

sourceString: Although questions remain, there is no evidence that SARS-CoV-2 is man-made either deliberately or accidentally.
targetString: Ata mituna ezali kaka, ezali te na bilembeteli emonisi ete SARS-CoV-2 esalemi na bato ezali na nko to na kidiba.
en-mt: While questions remain, there is no evidence that human-induced SARS-CoV-2 is deliberate or malicious.

sourceString: CoVs have returned to the limelight due to the recent outbreak of SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Bato bazongeli kolobela mingi CoVs mpo na epalangana ya sika ya SARS-CoV-2.
en-mt: There has been a renewed focus on CoVs due to the new SARS-CoV-2 outbreak.

sourceString: The study of CoVs in bats and other animals has drastically changed our perception of the importance of zoonotic origins and animal reservoirs of HCoVs in human transmission.
targetString: Boyekoli ya CoVs na bangembo mpe na banyama mosusu ebongoli mpenza ndenge na biso ya kotalela kondima soki HCoVs euta na banyama mpe banyama oyo ebombaka yango liboso epesa yango na bato.
en-mt: Studies of CoVs in baboons and other animals have dramatically changed our view of whether HCoVs originate from animals and animals that harbor them before transmitting them to humans.

sourceString: Pervasive evidence has shown that SARS-CoV, MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2 have a bat origin and are transmitted to humans via intermediate hosts.
targetString: Bilembeteli ya solo te emonisi ete SARS-CoV, MERS-CoV mpe SARS-CoV-2 euta na ngembo mpe ekotaka na bato na nzela ya biloko mosusu oyo ebombaka yango.
en-mt: There is no conclusive evidence that SARS-CoV, MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2 originate from mosquitoes and enter humans through other vectors.

sourceString: Given that SARS-CoV infection originates from the contact between humans and civets in the markets, closing wet markets and killing civets therein could have effectively ended the SARS epidemic.
targetString: Mpo maladi ya SARS-CoV euti na bokutani kati na bato mpe ba civet na bazando, kokanga bazando ya banyama ya mobesu mpe koboma ba civet oyo eza kuna ekokoki kosukisa maladi ya SARS.
en-mt: Because SARS-CoV is caused by contact between humans and civets in markets, closing wildlife markets and killing the civets there could end the SARS outbreak.

sourceString: By the same reasoning, pangolins should be removed from wet markets to prevent zoonotic transmission, in view of the discovery of multiple lineages of pangolin beta-CoVs closely related to SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Na makanisi moko wana, basengeli kolongola bapangolin na bazando ya banyama ya mobesu mpo na kokanga nzela ete banyama epesa biso te maladi wana, mpo makambo mingi emonisi ete ba beta-CoVs mingi oyo euti na pangolin ezali na boyokani na SARS-CoV-2.
en-mt: In the same vein, pangolins should be removed from poultry markets to prevent the animals from transmitting this disease to us, as there is considerable evidence that many pangolin-derived beta-CoVs are related to SARS-CoV-2.

sourceString: However, whether and how SARS-CoV-2 is transmitted to humans through pangolins and other mammals remain to be clarified in future investigations.
targetString: Kasi, bolukiluki oyo ekosalema na mokilo ezali koya ekosalisa na koyeba soki bato bazwaki mpenza SARS-CoV-2 na bapangolin mpe banyama mosusu.
en-mt: However, future studies will help determine if humans have actually contracted SARS-CoV-2 from pangolins and other animals.

sourceString: On the other hand, MERS-CoV has existed in dromedary camels for a long time.
targetString: Na ndambo mosusu, MERS-CoV ekotela bakamela dromadaire banda kala.
en-mt: On the other hand, MERS-CoV has been infecting dromadarian camels for a long time.

sourceString: These camels serve as an important tool for transportation as well as a main source of meat, milk, leather and wool products for the local people.
targetString: Bakamela bazali na mokumba ya ntina mpo na komema maladi wana na bato, lolenge moko na misuni, miliki, mposo ya nyama mpe biloko ya laine mpona bato ya mboka.
en-mt: Camels play an important role in transmitting the disease to humans, as do meat, milk, hides and wool products for the local people.

sourceString: They are widely distributed across the Middle East and Africa.
targetString: Ekabolama mingi na moyen orient mpe na Afrika.
en-mt: Widely distributed in the middle east and Africa.

sourceString: It is therefore impossible to sacrifice all camels for the control of MERS, as what was done in wild animal markets in China to prevent the spreading of SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Yango wana likoki ezali te ya koboma bakamela nyonso mpo na kobundisa MERS, ndenge esalemaki na bazando ya banyama ya zamba na Chinae mpo na kokanga SARS-CoV mpe SARS-CoV-2 nzela epanzana te.
en-mt: It is therefore not possible to slaughter all camels to combat MERS, as was done in wildlife markets in Chinae to stop SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2 from spreading.

sourceString: To stop the recurrent outbreaks of MERS, a comprehensive approach should be taken to develop effective vaccines against MERS-CoV for camels, in combination with other infection control measures.
targetString: Mpo na kokanga MERS nzela ebima lisusu te, tosengeli kosala bolukiluki ya malamu mpo na kobimisa mangwele ebongi mpo na MERS-CoV ya bakamela, mpe kotya bipekiseli mosusu mpo na kobundisa maladi wana.
en-mt: To stop MERS from re-emerging, we need to conduct effective research to develop an appropriate vaccine for camel MERS-CoV, and put in place additional restrictions to combat that disease.

sourceString: As we are not able to eliminate these viruses, new genotypes might emerge to cause outbreaks.
targetString: Lokolo tokoki te kosilisa bavirisi oyo, bagenome ya sika ekoki kobimisa maladi mosusu.
en-mt: Since we cannot eradicate these viruses, new genomes can cause other diseases.

sourceString: A variety of zoonotic CoVs are circulating in the wild.
targetString: Ba CoVs mingi ezali kotambola na kati ya zamba.
en-mt: Many CoVs are circulating in the wild.

sourceString: Particularly, bat CoVs with zoonotic potential are so diverse.
targetString: Mingimingi, CoVs ya banyama oyo ekoki kobima na lolenge mingi mpenza.
en-mt: In particular, these animal CoVs can occur in a myriad of forms.

sourceString: There are plenty of opportunities that these zoonotic CoVs evolve and recombine, resulting in the emergence of new CoVs that are more transmissible and/or deadly in humans in future.
targetString: Ezali na mabaku mingi mpenza mpo ba CoVs oyo ya banyama ekola mpe esangana lisusu, ebongo ebimisa CoVs ya sika oyo ekopanzana mingi mpe/to ekoboma bato mingi na mikolo ezali koya.
en-mt: There are far too many opportunities for these animal CoVs to grow and recombine, thus producing new CoVs that will spread more widely and/or kill more people in the future.

sourceString: The culture of eating wild animals in some places of China should be abandoned to reduce unnecessary contact between humans and animals.
targetString: Ezaleli ya kolya mbisi ya zamba na bisika mosusu ya Chine esengeli kosuka mpo bato bakutana lisusu mingi te na banyama.
en-mt: The practice of eating wild fish in some parts of China needs to end so that human contact with the animals is reduced.

sourceString: With the ordeals of SARS, MERS and COVID-19, a better preparedness and response plan should be in place.
targetString: Ndenge SARS, MERS mpe COVID-19 enyokoli biso, tosengeli komibongisa mpe kosala mwango ya kobundisa yango.
en-mt: As SARS, MERS and COVID-19 plague us, we need to prepare and plan to fight them.

sourceString: In fact, many viruses have existed in the planet for a very long time.
targetString: Ya solo, bavirisi mingi bafandi na planete na biso banda kala mpenza.
en-mt: Indeed, many viruses have inhabited our planet for a very long time.

sourceString: They stay in their own natural reservoirs until there is a chance for spillover.
targetString: Efandaka na bisika na yango kino ezwaka libaku ya kobima.
en-mt: It stays in its places until it has a chance to emerge.

sourceString: Although bats have many features that favours the spreading of viruses, the chance for humans to be in contact with bats and other wildlife species can be minimized if people are educated to stay away from them.
targetString: Ata ete bangembo bazali na bizaleli mingi oyo esalaka ete bavirisi wana epanzana mingi, tokoki kosala ete bato bakutana lisusu mingi te na bangembo mpe banyama mosusu ya zamba soki toteyi bato na kotikala mosika na banyama wana.
en-mt: Although ticks have many of the characteristics that make these viruses more likely to spread, we can reduce human exposure to ticks and other wildlife by educating people to stay away from these animals.

sourceString: Continuous surveillance in mammals is necessary for better understanding of the ecology of CoVs and their natural hosts, which will prove useful in preventing animal-to-human transmission and future outbreaks.
targetString: Kolanda kokengela bamamifere ezali ntina mingi mpo na koyeba ndenge CoVs ezalaka mpe bisika oyo yango efandaka, ebongo ekosalisa na kokanga nzela mpo banyama epesa te bato bavirisi wana mpe ebima lisusu te na mikolo ezali kooya.
en-mt: Continued surveillance of mammals is essential to understand the nature and habitat of CoVs, thus helping to prevent animal transmission of these viruses and future recurrence.

sourceString: To conclude, the most effective way to prevent viral zoonosis is for humans to stay away from the ecological niches of the natural reservoirs of the zoonotic viruses.
targetString: Mpo na kosukisa, lolenge eleki malamu ya kokanga nzela na bavirisi oyo eutaka na banyama ezali ete bato bazala mosika na bisika oyo banyama wana ya zamba oyo ezalaka na bavirisi wana efandaka.
en-mt: In conclusion, the best way to contain animal-borne viruses is for people to stay away from the habitats of these wild animals that carry these viruses.

sourceString: Several pieces in the puzzle of the zoonotic origin of SARS-CoV-2 are still missing.
targetString: Kino sikoyo toyebi nanu malamu te makambo mosusu etali esika oyo SARS-CoV-2 ya banyama eutaka.
en-mt: So far we still do not know enough about the source of animal SARS-CoV-2.

sourceString: First, if bats transmit an ancestral virus of SARS-CoV-2 to pangolins, it will be of interest to see under what circumstances bats and pangolins could share the same ecological niche.
targetString: Ya liboso, soki bangembo epesaki bapangolin virisi ya kala ya SARS-CoV-2, ekozala malamu na koyeba na ndenge nini bangembo na bapangolin bafandaka esika moko.
en-mt: First, if ticks infected pangolins with the old SARS-CoV-2 virus, it would be useful to know how ticks and pangolins coexist.

sourceString: Second, if bats play a more direct role in human transmission, how humans get into contact with bats should be determined.
targetString: Ya mibale, soki bangembo nde bato bapesaki mbala moko virisi wana na bato, esengeli toyeba ndenge nini bato bakutanaki na bangembo.
en-mt: Second, if insects directly transmitted the virus to humans, we need to know how humans were exposed to insects.

sourceString: Third, if a third mammal acts as the true intermediate host, how it interacts with the different species including humans, bats and pangolins has to be clarified.
targetString: Ya misato, soki mamifere ya misato nde azali esika ya mibale ya solo oyo virisi efandaka, esengeli kolimbola malamu ndenge nini ekutanaka na bikelamu mosusu ata mpe bato, bangembo mpe bapangolin.
en-mt: Third, if the third mammal is the second true host of the virus, its interactions with other organisms including humans, monkeys, and pangolins need to be well defined.

sourceString: Finally, since many mammals including domestic animals might be susceptible to SARS-CoV-2, both surveillance and experimental infection should be conducted.
targetString: Ya nsuka, mpo bamamifere mingi ata mpe banyama ya ndako ekoki kozala na SARS-CoV-2, esengeli mpe koluka kokengela yango mpe koluka koyeba soki ezalaka na maladi wana.
en-mt: Finally, because many mammals including domestic animals can be infected with SARS-CoV-2, surveillance and susceptibility testing should also be attempted.

sourceString: Should it be a bat, a pangolin or another mammal, it is expected that SARS-CoV-2 or its parental viruses that are almost identical will be identified in its natural hosts in future.
targetString: Ezali nde ngembo, pangolin to mamifere mosusu, esegami ete tozela SARS-CoV-2 to bavirisi mosusu oyo ebimisaka yango oyo ekokani mpenza na yango, ekoyebana na bisika oyo efandaka na mikolo ezali koya.
en-mt: Whether it is a deer, pangolin or other mammal, it is expected that SARS-CoV-2 or other viruses that cause it that are closely related to it will be identified in their habitats in the future.

sourceString: Continued investigations in this area will elucidate the evolutionary pathway of SARS-CoV-2 in animals, with important implications in the prevention and control of COVID-19 in humans.
targetString: Kokoba kolandela makambo wana ekoki kosalisa na koyeba ndenge SARS-CoV-2 ekolaka na banyama, mpe yango eza na bopusi mingi na kobundisa mpe kobatela bato na COVID-19.
en-mt: Continued monitoring of these data may help understand how SARS-CoV-2 develops in animals, and this has a significant impact on the fight against and protection against COVID-1

sourceString: Updating the diagnostic criteria of COVID-19 “suspected case” and “confirmed case” is necessary
targetString: Mis-à-jour ya boyebeli “cas bakaniseli” eza na bokono ya COVID-19 na “cas endimami” eza na ntina penza
en-mt: An update on the definition of “suspected case” of COVID-19 and “confirmed case” is very important

sourceString: On 6 February 2020, our team had published a rapid advice guideline for diagnosis and treatment of 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) infection, and this guideline provided our experience and make well reference for fighting against this pandemic worldwide.
targetString: Na 6 Février 2020, lisanga nabiso epubliaki lisungi ya toli ya bombango pona koyebela pe kobelisa bokono ya kpokoso ya coronavirus yasika 2019 (2019-nCoV), bongo lisungi yango epesaki lolenge ya biso toyebeli na bobelesi pona kobundisa pandemi oyo ya mokili mobimba.
en-mt: On February 6, 2020, our community published an emergency advisory tool for diagnosing and treating the 2019 pandemic coronavirus (2019-nCoV), so the tool provided our known approach to treatment to combat this global pandemic.

sourceString: However, the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a new disease, our awareness and knowledge are gradually increasing based on the ongoing research findings and clinical practice experience; hence, the strategies of diagnosis and treatment are also continually updated.
targetString: Kasi, bokono ya coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19) eza yasika, boyebi na bwania bwabiso mpona yango ezo mata moke-moke na botali makundoli mazo monana pe bisaleli ya cliniki bizo yebana; bongo wana nde eza bastrategie ya diaginositiki pe bobelesi ezo landama kotiama à jour.
en-mt: However, the 2019 coronavirus (COVID-19) is local, our knowledge and understanding of it is slowly increasing as evidence becomes available and clinical tools become available; so these are the diagnostic strategies and treatment is followed put up to date.

sourceString: In this letter, we answered one comment on our guideline and provided the newest diagnostic criteria of “suspected case” and “confirmed case” according to the latest Diagnosis and Treatment Guidelines for COVID-19 (seventh version) that issued by the National Health Committee of the People’s Republic of China.
targetString: Na mokanda oyo, topesaki eyano na commentaire moko na lisungi nabiso pe topesi critere ya boyebeli yasika-sika pona “cas bakaniseli” pe “cas endimami” na bolandi Diagnostiki ya suka penza lisungi ya kobelesa pona COVID-19 (version ya sambo) oyo ebimisami na bakonzi ya Comite National ya Sante ya Republika Populaire ya Chine.
en-mt: In this paper, we responded to a comment on our support and provided local identification criteria for “suspected cases” and “approved cases” following the release of the most recent Diagnosis of Treatment Support for COVID-19 (seventh version). by officials of the National Health Committee of the People’s Republic of China.

sourceString: In December 2019, the 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) has caused an outbreak, which is now officially named as the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) and the virus has been named severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).
targetString: Na Decemba 2019, coronavirus yasika 2019, (2019-nCoV) ebimisi kpokoso, oyo ezo bengama na loyalo bokono ya coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19) ebongo virus yango eye kobengama syndrome respiratoire acute coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).
en-mt: In December 2019, the local coronavirus 2019, (2019-nCoV) caused a pandemic, which is officially known as the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) so the virus is known as acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).

sourceString: On 11 March 2020, WHO characterized COVID-19 as a pandemic.
targetString: Na 11 Mars 2020, WHO elimboli COVID-19 mpo ebengama pandemie.
en-mt: On 11 March 2020, WHO defined COVID-19 as a pandemic.

sourceString: In order to fight against the SARS-CoV-2 infection, our team has developed a rapid advice guideline and that has been published online in Military Medical Research on 06 February 2020.
targetString: Mpona kobunda na bokono ya SARS-CoV-2, lisanga nabiso ekolisi lisungi ya toli ya bombango bongo yango nde ezali publie na molongo ya Interneti na Bokundoli ya Medical ya Basoda ya 06 Fefrier 2020.
en-mt: To combat SARS-CoV-2, our community has developed an emergency advisory service so that is what is published online in the Military Medical Memorial of 06 February

sourceString: It has attracted a great attention since published.
targetString: Ebendi batangi mingi banda publication na yango.
en-mt: It has attracted many readers since its publication.

sourceString: Note however that COVID-19 is a new disease, our awareness and knowledge is gradually increasing based on the ongoing research findings and clinical practice experience; hence, the strategies of diagnosis and treatment are also continually updated.
targetString: Kasi nde yeba ete COVID-19 eza yasika, boyebi na bwania bwabiso mpona yango ezo mata moke-moke na botali makundoli mazo monana pe bisaleli ya cliniki bizo yebana; bongo wana nde eza bastrategie ya diaginosiitiki pe bobelesi ezo landama kotiama à jour.
en-mt: But know that COVID-19 is local, our knowledge and intelligence about it is slowly increasing as evidence becomes available and clinical tools become available; so these are the diagnostic strategies and treatment is followed put up to date.

sourceString: For instance the Diagnosis and Treatment Guidelines for COVID-19 issued by the National Health Committee of the People’s Republic of China (http://www.nhc.gov.cn/), among 16 January 2020 to 3 March 2020, has issued a total of seven editions with some contexts being substantively changed.
targetString: Ndakisa masungi ya Diagnositiki na Bobelesi pona COVID-19 ebimisamaki na Comite National ya Sante ya Republika Populaire ya Chine (http://www.nhc.gov.cn/), kati-kati ya 16 Janvier 2020 tii 3 Mars 2020, esi ebimisi ba edition sambo bongo nde bacontexte mosusu ezali kobongwana makasi.
en-mt: For example the Diagnostic and Treatment guide for COVID-19 published by the National Health Committee of the People's Republic of China (http://www.nhc.gov.cn/), between January 16, 2020 and March 3, 2020, has already been published seven editions so some contexts are changing dramatically.

sourceString: Now our guideline received a comment by Zhou et al., they introduced a simple scoring proposal based on their clinical experience.
targetString: Sik’oyo lisungi nabiso ezwaki commentaire moko na Zhou et al., bakotisaki lolenge ya pete-pete ya kopesa bapoint na bolandi ya experience nabango ya cliniki.
en-mt: Now our contribution received a comment from Zhou et al., they introduced a simple scoring method in their clinical experience follow-up.

sourceString: Their work added new evidence for our guideline and also make valuable reference for this pandemic worldwide.
targetString: Mosala nabango ebakisi bilembo yasika mpo na lisungi pe esali botindi ya ntina pona pandemie mokili mobimba.
en-mt: Their work adds local clues to relief and creates an important referral for the global pandemic.

sourceString: We endorse their significant work and express our thanks.
targetString: Toyambi mosala nabango ya ntina monene pe totondi bango botondi.
en-mt: We welcome their important work and thank them.

sourceString: However, their work also needs update according to the latest Diagnosis and Treatment Guidelines for COVID-19 (Trial seventh version) and recently studies.
targetString: Kasi, mosala nabango pe ezo senga mis-à -jour na botali Masungi ya Diagnostiki pe Bobelesi yasika pona COVID-19 (Meka version ya sambo) mayekoli ma leki.
en-mt: However, their work also requires an update in view of the Diagnostic Support and Localization for COVID-19 (Try the seventh version) previous studies.

sourceString: According to the seventh edition (3 March 2020), to confirm the suspected case needs to combine any one item of epidemiological history features with two items of clinical manifestations to make a comprehensive analysis, or needs to meet three items of clinical manifestations if without clear epidemiological history:
targetString: Na bolandi edition ya sambo (3 Mars 2020), pona kondima cas bakaniseli ezo senga bosangisi ya itemi moko ya lisolo ya bikila-kila ya epidemiologie na ba itemi mibale ya ba manifestation ya cliniki pona kosala analyse mobimba, to eza na posa etondisa ba itemi misato ya ba manifestation ya cliniki soki ezangi moi ya nsango ya epidemiologie:
en-mt: According to the seventh edition (3 March 2020), case acceptance is considered to require the combination of one item of epidemiological medical history and two items of clinical manifestations to conduct a complete analysis, or it needs to fill in the items three clinical manifestations if without the sun of epidemiological information:

sourceString: Epidemiological history: (1) a history of travel or residence in Wuhan city and surrounding areas, or other communities where COVID-19 cases had been reported in the last 14 days before symptom onset; (2) a history of contact with SARS-CoV-2 infectious cases (with positive nucleic acid test); (3) a history of contacting with patients with fever or respiratory symptoms from Wuhan city and surrounding areas, or other communities where COVID-19 had been reported in the last 14 days before symptom onset; (4) a history of contacting with cluster of confirmed cases (≥ 2 cases with fever and/or respiratory symptoms occurred within 2 weeks in small areas, such as home, office, class of school, etc).
targetString: Nsango ya Epidemiologie: (1) nsango ya mobembo to ya bofandi na mboka Wuhan pe pembeni nango, to masanga mosusu ya bacas ya COVID-19 esalami lapolo mikolo 14 eleki liboso basymptomi ebanda; (2) nsango ya bokangani na cas ya SARS-CoV-2 (teste positive ya noyau ya acide nucleiki); (3) nsango ya bokangani ma mobeli ya nzoto fievre to basymptomi ya kopema awuti na mboka Wuhan na bisika ya pembeni to lisusu masanga mosusu esika basali lapolo ya bacas ya COVID-19 na mikolo 14 eleki liboso ya basymptomi ya ebandeli; (4) nsango ya bokangani na liboke ya bacas endimami (≥ cas 2 na fievre pe/to basymptomi ya kopema kati ya poso 2 na bisika mike, ndakisa ndako, bilo, kelasi ya sikola, bnb).
en-mt: Epidemiological Information: (1) information of travel or residence in and around Wuhan, or other groups of COVID-19 cases reported 14 days before the onset of symptoms; (2) linkage information to a SARS-CoV-2 case (nucleic acid nucleus positive test); (3) news of contact with a patient with fever or respiratory symptoms from Wuhan in neighboring areas or other communities where cases of COVID-19 have been reported in the past 14 days prior to initial symptoms; (4) confirmed case group contact information (≥ 2 cases with fever and/or respiratory symptoms within 2 weeks in small areas, eg home, office, school, bnb).

sourceString: Clinical manifestations: (1) fever and/ or respiratory symptoms; (2) with imaging features of COVID-19 infection; (3) total white blood cell counts showing normal, decreased, or reduced lymphocyte count in the early onset stage.
targetString: Bamanifestation ya cliniki: (1) fievre pe/to basymptomi ya bopemi; (2) na bilembo ya bilili ya bokono ya COVID-19 ; (3) lotango ya baglobule ya pembe nionso ezo lakisa normale, ekita, to lotango ya lymphocyte ekita na tango ya ebandeli.
en-mt: Clinical manifestations: (1) fever and/or respiratory symptoms; (2) with symptoms of COVID-19 images; (3) all white blood cell counts show normal, decreased, or decreased lymphocyte counts at baseline.

sourceString: Diagnosing the confirmed case should base on suspected case with any one item of pathogenic or serological evidence as following: (1) real-time PCR test positive for SARS-CoV-2; (2) viral whole genome sequencing showing high homogeneity to the known novel coronaviruses; (3) positive for the specific IgM antibody and IgG antibody to SARS-CoV-2 in serum test; or a change of the SARS-CoV-2-specific IgG antibody from negative to positive, or titer rising ≥4 times in the recovery phase above that in the acute phase.
targetString: Diagnostiki ya cas endimami esengeli ezala nase ya cas bakaniseli na itemi ata moko ya ekenenge to evidence ya serologie evidence lokola elandi awa: (1) teste ya PCR ya temps reel positive pona SARS-CoV-2; (2) bolandi ya genome mobimba ezo lakisa homogeneite emata na ba coronavirus yasika eyebani; (3) eza positive pona IgM specifiki ya anticorps pe IgG anticorps na SARS-CoV-2 na teste ya serume; to mbongwana na IgM ya SARS-CoV-2-specific IgG anticorps uta negative ti positive, to kobuta ya titer ≥ mbala 4 na phase ya recouvrement likolo ya cas phase ya songe.
en-mt: The diagnosis of an accepted case must be based on a suspected case with at least one item of evidence or serological evidence evidence as follows: (1) a positive real-time PCR test for SARS-CoV-2; (2) genome-wide sequencing shows increased homogeneity in coronaviruses of known location; (3) positive for antibody-specific IgM and IgG antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 by serum assay; or a change in IgM of SARS-CoV-2-specific IgG antibody from negative to positive, or a rise of titer ≥ 4-fold in the overlap phase over the mosquito phase case.

sourceString: We can see that the real-time PCR test for nucleic acid in respiratory tract or blood samples was added to the second (18 January 2020) and third (22 January 2020) editions.
targetString: Toko komona ete teste ya PCR ya temps reel pona acide nucleiki na nzela ya kopemela to echantillon ya makila ebakisamaki na ba edition ya mibale (18 Janvier 2020) pe ya misato (22 Janvier 2020).
en-mt: We will note that the real-time PCR test for nucleic acid by breath or blood sample was added in the second (January 18, 2020) and third (January 22, 2020) editions.

sourceString: The pathogenic detection of blood sample was added to the fourth (27 January 2020) and fifth (8 February 2020) editions; and then the serological evidence was added to the seventh edition.
targetString: Bokundoli ya ekenenge ya echantillon ya makila ebakisamaki na ba edition ya mine (27 Janvier 2020) pe ya mitano (8 Février 2020); pe evidence ya serologie ebakisamaki na edition ya sambo .
en-mt: The blood sample ekenenge summary was added in the fourth (January 27, 2020) and fifth (February 8, 2020) editions; and serological evidence was added in the seventh edition .

sourceString: These modifications based on the researchers continued work that to search for an optimal nucleic acid detection kit for rapid diagnosis, as well as the samples from respiratory tract including blood sampling, which increased the availability of different specimens, and supported bringing the specific antibody positive result into the confirmed criteria.
targetString: Bambongwana yango na botali ya bakundoli elandelaki mosala ete pona koluka bisaleli ya diaginositiki ya bombango pona bokundoli optimal ya acide nucleiki, elongo na echantillon ya nzela ya bopemeli tia nakati echantillon ya makila, mutu ebutisaki bobelemi ya ba endimeli ya ndenge ebele, pe esungaki bomemi ya resultat ya anticorps specifiki positive na bacritiki endimama.
en-mt: These changes in memory analysis followed the work that in finding early diagnostic tools for optimal nucleic acid memory, including respiratory tract samples including blood samples, one reduced the proximity of multiple beliefs, and supported the introduction of a positive specific antibody result in critically accepted.

sourceString: Besides, there are more and more evidence that remind us to caution with the atypical symptomatic and asymptomatic patients.
targetString: Lisusu, ba evidence ezo matisama oyo ezo rappeler biso ete to bimisa miso na babeli baza atypiki symptomatiki na asymptomatiki.
en-mt: Also, there is increasing evidence that reminds us to keep an eye out for patients who are atypically symptomatic and asymptomatic.

sourceString: Hence, the flow chart of Zhou et al. should be updated, as they classified the person without clinical symptoms as “low risk”.
targetString: Pona kolanda, graphiki ya Zhou et al. esengeli etiamama à jour, lokola batiaki moto azanga basymptome cliniki esika ya “riske ya moke“.
en-mt: For reference, the graph of Zhou et al. it should be updated, as a person without clinical symptoms is placed in a “low risk” area.

sourceString: The score system also needs to be verified in further clinical practice and studies.
targetString: Systemi ya ba point pe esengeli ezala vérifié na masaleli pe mayekoli ya cliniki ya kobakisa.
en-mt: The point system also needs to be verified with additional clinical tools and studies.

sourceString: To conclude, we hope more direct evidence coming up and call for readers to provide their comments.
targetString: Mpona kosukisa, toza na elikia ete ba evidence ya libela ekobakisama pe ebengi batangi bapesa ndenge bamoneli.
en-mt: Finally, we hope that permanent evidence will be added and invite readers to provide their views.

sourceString: For the diagnosis of “suspected case” and “confirmed case”, we suggest to trace and obey the newest guidelines of their home countries.
targetString: Mpona diaginositiki ya “cas ekaniselami” pe “endimami” tozo belela kolanda pe kotosa nde masungi yasika mazo uta na bikolo na bango.
en-mt: For the diagnosis of “suspected” and “confirmed” cases we call for following and following the local guidelines available from their countries.

sourceString: Our team will also timely update our guideline to offer help.
targetString: Lisanga nabiso pe ekosala mis a jour na tango ekoka lisungi nabiso pona kopesa lisalisi.
en-mt: Our community will also update in time our assistance to provide assistance.

sourceString: Bangladesh reports five new deaths due to COVID-19, a daily highest
targetString: Bangladesh epesi rapor ete bato misato bakufi na COVID-19, koleka mikolo misusu
en-mt: Bangladesh has reported three deaths from COVID-19, more than in previous days

sourceString: Yesterday, Bangladesh has confirmed five new deaths due to COVID-19 on the day.
