targetString: Na kati ya balaboratoire 16 oyo endimama, 7 ezali na Asie, 5 na Eropa, 2 na Afrika, 1 na Amerique ya norde mpe 1 na Australie.
en-mt: Of the 16 accredited laboratories, 7 are located in Asia, 5 in Europe, 2 in Africa, 1 in North America and 1 in Australia.

sourceString: In the following chart, the column “Positive as % of tests” is influenced by the country's testing policy.
targetString: Na tableau elandi, molongo “% ya bato bakangi na maladi” esalemi na kolanda bibongiseli ya mokili wana ezwi mpo na kosala ba ekzame.
en-mt: In the next table, the rank “% of people infected” is based on the organizations in the world that take to testing.

sourceString: A country that only tests people admitted to hospitals will have a higher positive as % of tests than a country that tests all citizens, whether or not they are showing symptoms, other things being equal.
targetString: Mokili oyo ezosalisa ekzame kaka na bato oyo bakoti lopitalo ekozala na % ya mingi ya bato oyo bakangi na maladi koleka mikili oyo ezosalisa bato nyonso ekzame, eza baza na bilembo to baza na yango te.
en-mt: A country that tests only hospitalized people will have a higher % of infections than countries that test everyone, whether they have symptoms or not.

sourceString: Hand washing (or handwashing), also known as hand hygiene, is the act of cleaning one's hands for the purpose of removing soil, grease, microorganisms, or other unwanted substances.
targetString: Kosokola maboko, oyo babengi mpe bopeto ya maboko, ezali kopetola maboko mpo na kolongola mabele, mafuta, mikrobe, mpe mbindo mosusu.
en-mt: Hand washing, also called hand hygiene, is the cleaning of hands to remove dirt, grease, germs, and other contaminants.

sourceString: Hand washing with soap consistently at certain "critical moments" during the day prevents the spread of many diseases, for example diarrhoea and cholera, which are transmitted through fecal–oral route.
targetString: Kosokola maboko na sabuni mbala mingi na bantango “mosusu ya ntina” na mokolo ekangaka maladi nzela epanzana te na bato mingi, na ndakisa pulupulu, oyo eutaka na nyei mpe epesamaka na monoko.
en-mt: Washing hands with soap often at “essential” times of the day prevents diseases from spreading to many people, such as measles, which is caused by saliva and is transmitted orally.

sourceString: People can also become infected with respiratory diseases such as influenza or the common cold, for example, if they do not wash their hands before touching their eyes, nose, or mouth (i.e., mucous membranes).
targetString: Bato bakoki mpe kokoma na maladi ya kopema lokola grippe to maladi ya malili, na ndakisa, soki bazali kosokola maboko te liboso ya kosimba miso, zolo, to monoko (na ndakisa bisika oyo mayi ya nzoto elekaka).
en-mt: People can also become infected with respiratory illnesses such as the flu or colds, for example, if they don’t wash their hands before touching their eyes, nose, or mouth (such as bodily fluid passages).

sourceString: The five critical moments during the day where washing hands with soap is important include: before and after defecation, after cleaning a child's bottom or changing nappies, before feeding a child, before eating and before and after preparing food or handling raw meat, fish, or poultry.
targetString: Bangonga mitano ya ntina mingi na mokolo ntango oyo kosokola maboko na sabuni ezali ntina ezali: liboso mpe nsima ya kosumba, nsima ya kopetola masoko ya mwana to kolongola kush, liboso ya koleisa mwana, liboso ya kolya mpe nsima ya kolamba bilei to kosimba mosuni ya mobesu, mbisi, to soso.
en-mt: The five most important hours of the day when washing hands with soap is important are: before and after shopping, after cleaning the baby's mouth or removing kush, before feeding the baby, before eating and after cooking food or handling meat a mouse, a fish, or a mouse.

sourceString: If water and soap are not available, hands can be cleaned with ash.The World Health Organization recommends washing hands:
targetString: Soki mai na sabuni ezali te, okoki kopetola maboko na putulu. Organisation mondiale ya Sante elendisi kosokola maboko:
en-mt: If soap and water are not available, you can clean your hands with dust. The World Health Organization recommends hand washing:

sourceString: Before, during, and after preparing food.
targetString: Liboso ya kolamba bilei, ntango ozali kolamba mpe na nsima.
en-mt: Before, during and after preparing food.

sourceString: Before and after caring for a sick person.
targetString: Liboso mpe nsima ya kosalisa moto ya maladi.
en-mt: Before and after treatment of the patient.

sourceString: After changing the diapers or cleaning up a child who has used the toilet.
targetString: Nsima ya kolongola mpe kolatisa mwana kush to kosokola mwana oyo auti na wese.
en-mt: After removing and dressing the baby kush or washing the baby from the wese.

sourceString: After blowing your nose, coughing or sneezing.
targetString: Nsima ya kosimba zolo, kokosola, to kosala itche.
en-mt: After touching the nose, coughing, or itching.

sourceString: After touching animal, animal feed, or animal waste.
targetString: Nsima ya kosimba banyama, bilei ya banyama, to bosoto ya banyama.
en-mt: After handling animals, animal feed, or animal waste.

sourceString: Medical hand hygiene refers to hygiene practices related to medical procedures.
targetString: Bopeto ya maboko mpo na minganga ezali kotalela makambo ya bopeto na ntango ya kosala mosala ya monganga.
en-mt: Hand hygiene for physicians addresses aspects of hygiene during the practice of medicine.

sourceString: Hand washing before administering medicine or medical care can prevent or minimize the spread of disease.
targetString: Kosokola maboko liboso ya kopesa nkisi to ya kasalisa moto ya maladi ekoki kokanga maladi nzela epanzana te to epanzana mingi te.
en-mt: Washing hands before administering medicine or treating a patient can prevent the disease from spreading or spreading more.

sourceString: The main medical purpose of washing hands is to cleanse the hands of pathogens (bacteria, viruses, or other microorganisms that can cause disease) and chemicals which can cause harm or diseases.
targetString: Ntina ya makasi ya kosokola maboko mpo na minganga ezali mpona kolongola biloko mabe (mikrobe, bavirisi, to bamikrobe misusu ya moke oyo ekoki kopesa maladi) mpe biloko mosusu oyo ekoki kosala biso mabe to kopesa maladi.
en-mt: The main purpose of hand washing for doctors is to remove harmful substances (germs, viruses, or other microorganisms that can cause disease) and other substances that can harm or cause disease.

sourceString: This is especially important for people who handle food or work in the medical field, but also an important practice for the general public.
targetString: Eza ntina mingi mpo na bato oyo basimbaka bilei to basalaka mosala ya monganga, kasi ezali mpe ntina mpona bato nyonso.
en-mt: It is especially important for people who handle food or work as a doctor, but it is also important for everyone.

sourceString: Hand washing has many health benefits, including minimizing the spread of influenza, coronavirus, and other infectious diseases; preventing infectious causes of diarrhea; decreasing respiratory infections;
targetString: Kosokola maboko ezali na matomba ebele ya malamu mpona kolongono ya nzoto, na ndakisa kokitisa kopalangana ya grippe, ya coronavirisi, mpe ya maladi mosusu; kokanga nzela na biloko ememaka pulupulu; mpe kokitisa maladi ya mpema;
en-mt: Hand washing has many health benefits, such as reducing the spread of the flu, coronavirus, and other diseases; blocking the road to objects that carry pneumonia; and reduce respiratory disease;

sourceString: and reducing infant mortality rate at home birth deliveries.
targetString: mpe kokitisa motango ya liwa ya bana ya mike oyo babotamaka na ndako.
en-mt: and reducing infant mortality at home.

sourceString: A 2013 study showed that improved hand washing practices may lead to small improvements in the length growth in children under five years of age.
targetString: Na 2013 bolukiluki moko oyo emonisaki ete ezaleli ya kosokola maboko ekoki kobongola mwa moke bokoli ya bana oyo bakokisi naino te mbula 5.
en-mt: In 2013 a study that found that hand washing behavior can slightly alter the development of children under 5 years of age.

sourceString: In developing countries, childhood mortality rates related to respiratory and diarrheal diseases can be reduced by introducing simple behavioral changes, such as hand washing with soap.
targetString: Na mikili ya bobola, motango ya liwa ya bana oyo bakufaka na maladi ya mpema mpe na pulupulu ekoki kokita kaka soki tobongoli bizaleli, na ndakisa kosokola maboko na sabuni.
en-mt: In poor countries, child mortality from respiratory diseases and pneumonia can be reduced only by changing behaviors, such as washing hands with soap.

sourceString: This simple action can reduce the rate of mortality from these diseases by almost 50%.
targetString: Likambo oyo ya moke ekoki kokitisa motango ya liwa ya bana na maladi oyo na pene ya 50%.
en-mt: This small step can reduce the child mortality rate in this disease by about 50%.

sourceString: Interventions that promote hand washing can reduce diarrhoea episodes by about a third, and this is comparable to providing clean water in low income areas.
targetString: Misala oyo ezali kolendisa kosokola maboko ekoki kokotisa maladi ya pulupulu mbala misato, mpe ezali ntina ndenge moko na kopesa mai ya peto na mikili ya bobola.
en-mt: Practices that promote hand washing can triple the risk of tuberculosis, and are equally important as providing clean water in poor countries.

sourceString: 48% of reductions in diarrhoea episodes can be associated with hand washing with soap.Hand washing with soap is the single most effective and inexpensive way to prevent diarrhea and acute respiratory infections (ARI), as automatic behavior performed in homes, schools, and communities worldwide.
targetString: 48% ya kokita ya maladi ya pulupulu ekoki kouta na kosokola maboko na sabuni. Kosokola maboko na sabuni lolenge ya pete koleka mpe ya ntalo mingi te ya kokanga nzela na maladi neti pulupulu mpe maladi ya mpema (ARI), ezali ezaleli ya ntina oyo tosengeli kozala na yango na bandako, na biteyelo, mpe na bisika nyonso na mokili mobimba.
en-mt: 48% of the reduction in pneumonia can be attributed to washing hands with soap. Washing hands with soap is the easiest and cheapest way to prevent diseases such as pneumonia and respiratory infections (ARI), and is an important habit to have in homes, schools, and everywhere around the world . . . .

sourceString: Pneumonia, a major ARI, is the number one cause of mortality among children under five years old, taking the lives of an estimated 1.8 million children per year.
targetString: Pneumonie maladi makasi ya ARI, ezali maladi ya liboso oyo ebomaka bana mingi oyo bazali na mbu nse ya mitano, ebomaka bana pene ya 1.8 milio mbula nyonso.
en-mt: ARI pneumonia is the leading cause of death among children in the sea, killing nearly 1.8 million children each year.

sourceString: Diarrhea and pneumonia together account for almost 3.5 million child deaths annually.
targetString: Pulupulu na pneumonie ebomaka bana pene ya 3,5 milio mbula nyonso.
en-mt: Measles and pneumonia kill about 3.5 million children each year.

sourceString: According to UNICEF, turning hand washing with soap before eating and after using the toilet into an ingrained habit can save more lives than any single vaccine or medical intervention, cutting deaths from diarrhea by almost half and deaths from acute respiratory infections by one-quarter.
targetString: UNICEF alobi ete, kokomisa kosokola maboko na sabuni liboso ya kolya mpe nsima ya kouta na wese bizaleli ya kati na biso ekoki kobikisa bato mingi koleka mangwele to nkisi nyonso, ekokitisa motango ya bato bazali kokufa na pulupulu na katikati mpe bato bazali kokufa na maladi makasi ya mpema na ndambo moko na kati ya minei.
en-mt: According to UNICEF, making washing hands with soap before meals and after going to bed a habit of ours could save more lives than any vaccine or medicine, halve the number of deaths from pneumonia and deaths from serious illnesses of breath in one-fourth.

sourceString: Hand washing is usually integrated together with other sanitation interventions as part of water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) programmes.
targetString: Kosokola maboko ezalaka mingimingi elongo na baprograme mosusu ya kosalela mai, kopetola mpe kolongono ya nzoto (KOSOKOLA).
en-mt: Hand washing is usually accompanied by other water use, sanitation and hygiene programs (WASHING).

sourceString: Hand washing also protects against impetigo which is transmitted through direct physical contact.
targetString: Kosokola maboko ebatelaka mpe na impetigo oyo epesamaka soki bato basimbani.
en-mt: Hand washing also protects against contact-transmitted impetigo.

sourceString: A small detrimental effect of hand washing is that frequent hand washing can lead to skin damage due to drying of the skin.
targetString: Mabe moko kaka ya kosokola maboko ezali ete kosokola maboko mbala mingi ekoki kobebisa mposo ya nzoto mpe ekoki kokausa yango.
en-mt: The only downside to hand scrubbing is that frequent hand scrubbing can damage the skin and dry it out.

sourceString: A 2012 Danish study found that excessive hand washing can lead to an itchy, flaky skin condition known as hand eczema or hand dermatitis, which is especially common among health-care workers.
targetString: Bolukiluki moko ya Danemark ya 2012 emonaki ete kolekisa ndelo na kosokola maboko ekoki kopesa mokosa, kolongola bamposo na maboko oyo ebengami eczema to dermatite ya maboko, oyo ekomelaka mingi minganga.
en-mt: A 2012 Danish study found that excessive hand washing can cause a skin rash called eczema or hand dermatitis, which is commonly prescribed by doctors.

sourceString: Too frequent hand washing is also seen as one of the symptoms of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).
targetString: Kosokola maboko koleka ndelo ezali mpe moko ya bilembo ya maladi ebengami maladi ya likama ya motungisi (OCD).
en-mt: Excessive hand washing is also one of the symptoms of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).

sourceString: There are five critical times during the day where washing hands with soap is important to reduce fecal-oral transmission of disease: after using the bathroom (urination, defecation), after cleaning a child's bottom (changing nappies), before feeding a child, before eating and before/after preparing food or handling raw meat, fish, or poultry.
targetString: Ezali na bantango mitano ya ntina na moko oyo kosokola maboko na sabuni ezali ntina mingi mpo na kokitisa motango ya kopesa maladi longwa na nyei ekota na monoko: nsima ya kouta na wese (kosuba, kosumba), nsima ya kosokola mwana masoko (kolongola mpe kolatisa kush), liboso ya koleisa mwana, liboso ya kolya mpe liboso/nsima ya kolamba bilei to ya kosimba mosuni ya mobesu, to soso.
en-mt: There are five important times in one when washing hands with soap is critical to reducing the rate of transmission from saliva into the mouth: after coming out of the toilet (washing, rinsing), after washing the baby’s genitals (removing and dressing). kush), before feeding, before meals and before/after cooking food or handling raw meat, or rat.

sourceString: Other occasions when correct handwashing technique should be practiced in order to prevent the transmission of disease include before and after treating a cut or wound; after sneezing, coughing, or blowing your nose; after touching animal waste or handling animals; and after touching garbage.
targetString: Mabaku mosusu ntango oyo kosokola maboko malamu esengeli kozala ezaleli mpo na kokanga maladi nzela ya kopanzana ezali kosokola maboko liboso mpe nsima ya kosalisa mpota; nsima ya kosala itye, ya kokosola, ya kosimba zolo; nsima ya kosimba bosoto ya banyama to ya kosimba banyama; mpe nsima ya kosimba bosoto.
en-mt: Other occasions when proper hand washing should be a habit to arrest the spread of disease are hand washing before and after wound treatment; after making itye, of coughing, of touching the nose; after handling animal waste or handling animals; and after handling dirt.

sourceString: In many countries, there is a low rate of hand washing with soap.
targetString: Na mikili mingi, bato mingi te basokolaka maboko na sabuni.
en-mt: In many countries, few people wash their hands with soap.

sourceString: A study of hand washing in 54 countries in 2015 found that on average, 38.7% of households practiced hand washing with soap.A 2014 study showed that Saudi Arabia had the highest rate of 97 percent; the United States near the middle with 77 percent; and China with the lowest rate of 23 percent.Several behaviour change methodologies now exist to increase uptake of the behaviour of hand washing with soap at the critical times.Group hand washing for school children at set times of the day is one option in developing countries to engrain hand washing in children's behaviors.
targetString: Bolukiluki moko na ntina ya kosokola maboko oyo esalemaki na mikili 54 na 2015 emonisi ete, bandako 38,7% basokolaka maboko na sabuni. Na 2014 bolukiluki moko emonisaki ete Arabie Saudite eza na motango makasi 97 pourcent; États-Unis ezalaki pene ya kati na 77 pourcent; mpe Chine na nse makasi na 23 pourcent. Misala mingi ezali lelo oyo ebongoli bizaleli ya kosokola maboko na mai mpe sabuni na bantango ya ntina. Kosokola maboko elongo moko mpo na bana ya kelasi na bangonga oyo etyama na mokolo ezali likanisi moko na mikili ya bobola mpo na kokotisa yango na bizaleli ya bana.
en-mt: A survey on hand washing conducted in 54 countries in 2015 found that 38.7% of households wash their hands with soap. In 2014 a survey found that Saudi Arabia has a whopping 97 percent; The United States was near the middle at 77 percent; and China sharply down at 23 percent. Several practices exist today that change hand washing behaviors with soap and water at critical times. Washing hands together for school children at set times of the day is an idea in developing countries to instill in children's behaviour.

sourceString: The "Essential Health Care Program" implemented by the Department of Education in the Philippines is an example of at scale action to promote children's health and education.
targetString: “Programe ya Ntina mpo na Kolongono ya Nzoto” oyo emekamaki Minstere ya Mateya ya Philippines eza ndakisa ya misala mpona kokolisa kolongono ya nzoto ya bana mpe kotanga na bango.
en-mt: The “Essential Health Program” piloted by the Philippine Ministry of Education is an example of activities to promote children's health and education.

sourceString: Deworming twice a year, supplemented with washing hands daily with soap, brushing teeth daily with fluoride, is at the core of this national program.
targetString: Kolongola misopo mbala mibale na mbula, elongo moko na kosokola maboko mikolo nyonso na sabuni, kosokola mino mikolo nyonso na nkisi ya mino, ezali makambo ya ntina mingi ya programe ya mboka.
en-mt: Twice-yearly defecation, along with daily hand washing with soap, daily toothpaste brushing, are the most important aspects of the village program.

sourceString: It has also been successfully implemented in Indonesia.
targetString: Basi basalela yango na Indonésie mpe ebimisa mbuma kitoko.
en-mt: It has been used in Indonesia with wonderful results.

sourceString: Removal of microorganisms from skin is enhanced by the addition of soaps or detergents to water.
targetString: Kolongola mikrobe na mposo ya nzoto esalemaka malamu soki babakisa kosalela sabuni to nkisi ya koboma mikrobe na mai.
en-mt: Skin decontamination is best accomplished by supplementing the use of soap or water disinfectant.

sourceString: The main action of soaps and detergents is to reduce barriers to solution, and increase solubility.
targetString: Mosala makasi ya sabuni mpe bankisi ya bopeto ezali mpona kofungola nzela ya kosalisa, mpe komatisa makasi na yango.
en-mt: The power of soaps and cleaning products is to open the way for treatment, and increase its effectiveness.

sourceString: Water alone is an inefficient skin cleanser because fats and proteins, which are components of organic soil, are not readily dissolved in water.
targetString: Kaka mai mpe ekoki kopetola malamu mposo ya nzoto mpo mafuta na baproteine, oyo bazali ya mabele, mai ekokaka te koboma yango na kati ya mayi.
en-mt: Only water can also cleanse the skin effectively because oils and proteins, which are earthy, cannot be killed by water in water.

sourceString: Cleansing is, however, aided by a reasonable flow of water..
targetString: Kasi, kopetolama esalemaka malamu soki babakiseli yango mai oyo ekoki.
en-mt: Cleaning, however, is best accomplished when sufficient water is added.

sourceString: Solid soap, because of its reusable nature, may hold bacteria acquired from previous uses.
targetString: Sabuni ya makasi, mpo bakoki kosalela yango lisusu, ekoki kozala na mikrobe euti na bato basalelaki yango liboso.
en-mt: Hard soap, because it can be reused, can contain germs from previous users.

sourceString: A small number of studies which have looked at the bacterial transfer from contaminated solid soap have concluded transfer is unlikely as the bacteria are rinsed off with the foam.
targetString: Mwa ndambo ya bolukiluki oyo esalemaki mpo na komona ndenge sabuni ya makasi elekisaka mikrobe na bato mosusu elobaki ete ekoki te kopesa mikrobe mpo bapangusaka mikrobe na fulufulu.
en-mt: Some studies on the transmission of germs from hard soaps have suggested that they are less contagious because they wipe germs off with a slime.

sourceString: The CDC still states "liquid soap with hands-free controls for dispensing is preferable".
targetString: Kasi, CDC elobi ete “sabuni ya mai oyo ezangi esika ya kosimba ezali malamu mingi mpo na kokanga maladi nzela epanzana te.”
en-mt: However, the CDC says that “contactless liquid soap is the best way to prevent the spread of disease.”

sourceString: Antibacterial soaps have been heavily promoted to a health-conscious public.
targetString: Bato mingi balobi ete ezali malamu bato oyo bakipaka kolongono ya nzoto basalela sabuni oyo ezali na nkisi ebomaka mikrobe.
en-mt: Many people recommend that health-conscious people use antiseptic soap.

sourceString: To date, there is no evidence that using recommended antiseptics or disinfectants selects for antibiotic-resistant organisms in nature.
targetString: Na mokolo ya lelo, eza na elembeli moko te ezali komonisa ete bazali kolendisa bato na kosalela antiseptique to nkisi ya koboma mikrobe oyo bapona mpona koboma mikrobe oyo ya mokili
en-mt: To date, there is no evidence that the use of antiseptics or disinfectants of choice to kill these global bacteria is being encouraged

sourceString: However, antibacterial soaps contain common antibacterial agents such as triclosan, which has an extensive list of resistant strains of organisms.
targetString: Kasi, mbala mingi sabuni ezali na nkisi ebomaka mikrobe ezalaka na nkisi ya koboma mikrobe neti triclosan, oyo ezali na mingi ya bamikrobe balendaka na mokili.
en-mt: However, soaps often contain antibiotics such as triclosan, which contains most of the world's bacteria.

sourceString: So, even if antibiotic resistant strains aren't selected for by antibacterial soaps, they might not be as effective as they are marketed to be.
targetString: Yango wana, ata soki ba antibiotique oyo elendaka eponami te na sabuni ezali na nkisi ya koboma mikrobe, ntango mosusu ezalaka makasi te ndenge elibami.
en-mt: Therefore, even if the antibiotics that are not selected in soap have antimicrobial properties, they are sometimes not as strong as claimed.

sourceString: Besides the surfactant and skin-protecting agent, the sophisticated formulations may contain acids (acetic acid, ascorbic acid, lactic acid) as pH regulator, antimicrobially active benzoic acid and further skin conditioners (aloe vera, vitamins, menthol, plant extracts).A comprehensive analysis from the University of Oregon School of Public Health indicated that plain soaps are as effective as consumer-grade anti-bacterial soaps containing triclosan in preventing illness and removing bacteria from the hands.
targetString: Longola biloko ya likolo mpe oyo ebatelaka mposo ya nzoto, bankisi ya mindondo ekoki kozala na aside (aside asetique, aside ascrobique, aside lastique) neti ebongiselo ya pH, aside benzoique oyo ebomaka mikrobe, mpe biloko mosusu elembisaka mposo ya nzoto (aloe vera, bavitamine, menthole, biloko euti na banzete). Bolukiluki ya Université ya Oregon ya Kolongono ya nzoto ya bato nyonso emonisi ete sabuni oyo ezali kati na biso esalisaka mingi ndenge moko na sabuni ezali na nkisi ya koboma mikrobe ezalaka na triclosan mpona kobundisa maladi mpe kolongola mikrobe na maboko.
en-mt: In addition to topical and protective ingredients, complex medications may contain acids (acetic acid, ascrobic acid, rubber acid) such as pH regulators, antibacterial benzoic acid, and other skin softeners (aloe vera, vitamins, menthol, plant extracts). Research by the University of Oregon Public Health shows that the soap in us is as effective as soap containing a disinfectant containing triclosan to fight infection and remove germs from hands.

sourceString: Hot water that is comfortable for washing hands is not hot enough to kill bacteria.
targetString: Mai ya moto ya kosokola maboko oyo ezali na moto makasi te ebomaka mikrobe te.
en-mt: Low-temperature hot water for washing hands does not kill germs.

sourceString: Bacteria grow much faster at body temperature (37 °C).
targetString: Mikrobe ekolaka noki na nzoto oyo ezali na temperature ya (37 °C).
en-mt: Bacteria grow faster at a body temperature of (37 °C).

sourceString: However, warm, soapy water is more effective than cold, soapy water at removing natural oils which hold soils and bacteria.
targetString: Kasi, mai ya moto, oyo ezali na sabuni esalisaka mingi kolongola mafuta mpe mabele mpe mikrobe koleka mai ya malili.
en-mt: However, hot, soapy water is more effective at removing grease and dirt and germs than cold water.

sourceString: Contrary to popular belief however, scientific studies have shown that using warm water has no effect on reducing the microbial load on hands.
targetString: Kasi na kokesena na makanisi ya bato mingi, bolukiluki ya bato ya siansi emonisi ete kosalela mai ya moto esalisaka te na kolongola mikrobe na maboko.
en-mt: But contrary to popular belief, scientific research shows that using hot water does not help remove germs from hands.

sourceString: A hand sanitizer or hand antiseptic is a non-water-based hand hygiene agent.
targetString: Nkisi ya kopetola maboko to antiseptique ya maboko eza nkisi ya kopetola maboko oyo esalelaka mai te.
en-mt: Hand sanitizer or hand antiseptic is a hand sanitizer that doesn’t use water.

sourceString: In the late 1990s and early part of the 21st century, alcohol rub non-water-based hand hygiene agents (also known as alcohol-based hand rubs, antiseptic hand rubs, or hand sanitizers) began to gain popularity.
targetString: Na nsuka ya mibu 1990 mpe na ebandeli ya siekle ya 21, nkisi ya kopetola maboko oyo esalelaka mai te (oyo babengaka mpe alcol ya kopetola maboko, antiseptique ya maboko, to nkisi ya maboko, ebandaki kosalelama mingi.
en-mt: In the late 1990s and early 21st century, non-water hand sanitizers (also called hand sanitizers, hand antiseptics, or hand sanitizers, became popular.

sourceString: Most are based on isopropyl alcohol or ethanol formulated together with a thickening agent such as Carbomer (polymer of acrylic acid) into a gel, or a humectant such as glycerin into a liquid, or foam for ease of use and to decrease the drying effect of the alcohol.
targetString: Mingi basalaka yango na alcol isopropyle to ethanole elongo na eloko neti Carbomer (polymer ya aside acrylique) na gel, to humectant na ndakisa glycerine na mai, to fulufulu mpo na kosalela yango malamu mpe kolembisa makasi ya kokausa ya alcol.
en-mt: Most are made with isopropyl alcohol or ethanol along with something like Carbomer (an acrylic acid polymer) in a gel, or a humectant such as glycerin in water, or a solution to make it easier to use and weaken the drying effect of the alcohol.

sourceString: Adding diluted hydrogen-peroxide increases further  the antimicrobial activity.Hand sanitizers containing a minimum of 60 to 95% alcohol are efficient germ killers.
targetString: Kobakisa hydrogene-peroxide ya maimai ematisaka mosala ya nkisi ebomaka mikrobe. Nkisi ya koboma mikrobe oyo ezali na alcol 60 kino 95% ezali makasi na koboma mikrobe.
en-mt: The addition of liquid hydrogen-peroxide increases the antimicrobial activity of the drug. Disinfectants containing 60 to 95% alcohol are potent in killing bacteria.

sourceString: Alcohol rub sanitizers kill bacteria, multi-drug resistant bacteria (MRSA and VRE), tuberculosis, and some viruses (including HIV, herpes, RSV, rhinovirus, vaccinia, influenza, and hepatitis) and fungi.
targetString: Nkisi ya koboma mikrobe ezali na alcol ebomaka mikrobe, mikrobe oyo ekufaka te na nkisi ya mbuma (MRSA mpe VRE), tuberculose, mpe bavirisi mosusu (ata mpe SIDA, herpes, RSV, rhinovirisi, mangwele, grippe mpe hepatite) mpe champignon.
en-mt: Disinfectants include alcohol kills germs, fruit resistant bacteria (MRSA and VRE), tuberculosis, and other viruses (including AIDS, herpes, RSV, rhinoviruses, vaccines, influenza, and hepatitis) and fungus.

sourceString: Alcohol rub sanitizers containing 70% alcohol kill 99.97% (3.5 log reduction, similar to 35 decibel reduction) of the bacteria on hands 30 seconds after application and 99.99% to 99.999% (4 to 5 log reduction) of the bacteria on hands 1 minute after application.Hand sanitizers are most effective against bacteria and less effective against some viruses.
targetString: Nkisi ya kopetola maboko oyo ezali na alcol 70% ebomaka 99,97% (ekitisaka log na 3,5, mpe ekotisaka decibel na 35) ya mikrobe na maboko basegonde 30 nsima ya kosalela yango mpe 99,99% kino na 99,999% (ekitisaka log na 4 kino 5) ya mikrobe na maboko miniti 1 nsima ya kosalela yango. Nkisi ya kopetelo maboko ezali makasi mingi na koboma mikrobe kasi ezali makasi te na koboma bavirisi mosusu.
en-mt: A 70% alcohol hand sanitizer kills 99.97% (reduces the log by 3.5, and introduces a decibel to 35) of germs on hands 30 seconds after use and 99.99% to 99.999% (reduces). log with 4 to 5) of bacteria on hands 1 minute after application. Hand sanitizer is very effective at killing germs but not at killing some viruses.

sourceString: Alcohol-based hand sanitizers are almost entirely ineffective against norovirus (or Norwalk) type viruses, the most common cause of contagious gastroenteritis.Enough hand antiseptic or alcohol rub must be used to thoroughly wet or cover both hands.
targetString: Nkisi ya kopetola maboko oyo ezali na alcol ekokaka ata moke te bavirisi ebengami norovirisi (to Norwalk), oyo epanzaka mbala mingi mikrobe na misopo. Esengeli kosala antiseptique to alcol ya kosokola maboko na mingi oyo ekopɔlisa mpenza maboko nyonso mibale to ekotonda likolo na yango.
en-mt: Alcohol-based hand sanitizers are never effective against viruses called norovirus (or Norwalk), which often spread bacteria in the urine. Antiseptic or hand rubbing alcohol should be applied in large quantities that will completely soak both hands or saturated the surface.

sourceString: The front and back of both hands and between and the ends of all fingers are rubbed for approximately 30 seconds until the liquid, foam or gel is dry.
targetString: Liboso mpe nsima ya maboko nyonso mibale mpe katikati ya maboko mpe kosokola bansuka ya manzaka na basegonde 30 kino mai, fulufulu to gel ekokauka.
en-mt: Front and back of both hands and middle of hands and scrub ends of sleeves for 30 seconds until water, slurry or gel dries.

sourceString: Finger tips must be washed well too, rubbing them in both palms.The US Center for Disease Control and Prevention recommends hand washing over hand sanitizer rubs, particularly when hands are visibly dirty.
targetString: Esengaka kosokola mpe nsonge ya manzaka, kokutanisa yango na maboko nyonso mibale. Centre ya États-Unis mpona kolandela maladi mpe kobatela yango elobi ezali malamu mingi kosokola maboko na esika ya kosalela nkisi ya kopetola maboko, mingimingi soki maboko ezali mpenza mbindo.
en-mt: It requires sewing and the tip of the handle, meeting it with both hands. The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says it is better to wash your hands than to use hand sanitizer, especially if your hands are very dirty.

sourceString: The increasing use of these agents is based on their ease of use and rapid killing activity against micro-organisms; however, they should not serve as a replacement for proper hand washing unless soap and water are unavailable.
targetString: Bato bazali kosalela mingi nkisi ya mai ya kopetola maboko mpo ezali pete na kosalela mpe ebomaka mikrobe noki; kasi, tokoki kosalela yango te na esika ya kosokola maboko malamu na mai, kasi tokosalela yango kaka soki mai na savon ezali te.
en-mt: Liquid hand sanitizers are increasingly used because they are easy to use and kill germs quickly; however, we cannot use it instead of washing our hands thoroughly with water, but we will use it only when soap and water are not available.

sourceString: Frequent use of alcohol-based hand sanitizers can cause dry skin unless emollients and/or skin moisturizers are added to the formula.
targetString: Kosalela mbala mingi nkisi ya kopetola maboko ezali na alcol ekoki kokausa mposo ya nzoto longola kaka soki babakisa na kati na yango biloko ekomisaka maboko sembesembe.
en-mt: Frequent use of alcohol-based hand sanitizer can dry out the skin unless hand conditioning agents are added.

sourceString: The drying effect of alcohol can be reduced or eliminated by adding glycerin and/or other emollients to the formula.
targetString: Bakoki kolembisa to kolongola makasi ya alcol ya kokausa maboko soki babakisi glycerine mpe/to biloko mosusu oyo ekomisaka maboko sembesembe.
en-mt: They can weaken or eliminate the alcohol’s severity of hand drying by adding glycerin and/or other smoothing agents.

sourceString: In clinical trials, alcohol-based hand sanitizers containing emollients caused substantially less skin irritation and dryness than soaps or antimicrobial detergents.
targetString: Na ntango ya komeka mangwele na bato, bankisi ya kopetola maboko esalemi na alcol oyo ezali na biloko ekomisaka maboko pete, esalaki mokusa moke na mposo ya nzoto mpe ekausaki maboko mingi te neti basavon to bankisi oyo ebomaka mikrobe.
en-mt: During human trials, alcohol-based hand sanitizers contained softening agents, caused less dryness in the skin and did not dry the hands as much as soaps or disinfectants.

sourceString: Allergic contact dermatitis, contact urticaria syndrome or hypersensitivity to alcohol or additives present in alcohol hand rubs rarely occur.
targetString: Mbala mingi mposo ya nzoto ekomaki te motane, ebimisaki te bambuma mpe eboyaki te bankisi esalemi na alcol to oyo batyaki bilangwiseli mosusu.
en-mt: The skin often did not turn red, rash, or resist alcohol-based or drug-based medications.

sourceString: The lower tendency to induce irritant contact dermatitis became an attraction as compared to soap and water hand washing.
targetString: Bato bakomaki kosepela mingi na kosalela bankisi oyo ekomisaka te mposo ya nzoto motane kasi te sabuni na mai mpo na kosokola maboko.
en-mt: People became more interested in using anti-tank products but not soap and water for hand washing.

sourceString: Despite their effectiveness, non-water agents do not cleanse the hands of organic material, but simply disinfect them.
targetString: Ata ezali makasi, bankisi ya kopela maboko oyo ezali na mai elongolaka te na maboko na biloko ya organique, kasi epetolaka yango kaka.
en-mt: Even though they’re strong, wet hand sanitizers don’t manually strip the hands of organics, but still clean them.

sourceString: It is for this reason that hand sanitizers are not as effective as soap and water at preventing the spread of many pathogens, since the pathogens still remain on the hands.
targetString: Yango wana bankisi ya kopetola maboko ezali kosalisama mingi te soki tokokanisi yango na sabuni mpe mai mpo na kokanga mikrobe mingi nzela epanzana te, mpo mikrobe etikalaka na maboko.
en-mt: That is why hand sanitizers are less effective than soap and water to prevent more germs from spreading, as germs remain on the hands.

sourceString: Alcohol-free hand sanitizer efficacy is heavily dependent on the ingredients and formulation, and historically has significantly under-performed alcohol and alcohol rubs.
targetString: Makasi ya bankisi ya kopetola maboko ezangi alcol eutaka mingi na biloko babakisaka na kati mpe na ndenge basalaka yango, mpe emonani ete eleki te nkisi ezali na alcol mpe oyo ezali na ntuku nsambo ya alcol.
en-mt: The strength of alcohol-free hand sanitizers is largely derived from the additives and formulation, and does not appear to be superior to alcohol-based and seventy-alcohol medications.

sourceString: More recently, formulations that use benzalkonium chloride have been shown to have persistent and cumulative antimicrobial activity after application, unlike alcohol, which has been shown to decrease in efficacy after repeated use, probably due to progressive adverse skin reactions.
targetString: Kala mingi te, bankisi oyo batyaka chlorure ya benzalkonium ezalaki koboma mpenza mikrobe nsima ya kopakola yango, na bokeseni na alcol, oyo emonanaki ete makasi na yango esilaka soki basaleli yango mingi, mbala mosusu mpo ezalaka na ba matoma mingi na mposo ya nzoto.
en-mt: Until recently, benzalkonium chloride sprays were highly antibacterial after application, unlike alcohol, which was found to lose its potency with excessive use, perhaps because of its high porosity in the skin.

sourceString: Many people in low-income communities cannot afford soap and use ash or soil instead.
targetString: Na bisika ya bobola, bato bakoki kosomba sabuni mpe kosalela putulu to mabele na esika na yango.
en-mt: In poor areas, people can buy soap and use dust or dirt instead.

sourceString: Ash or soil may be more effective than water alone, but may be less effective than soap.
targetString: Putulu to mabele ekoki kozala makasi mingi koleka mai yango moko, kasi ezali makasi te neti sabuni.
en-mt: Dust or soil may be much harder than water itself, but it is not as hard as soap.

sourceString: One concern is that if the soil or ash is contaminated with microorganisms it may increase the spread of disease rather than decrease it.
targetString: Eloko moko ezali kotungisa ezali ete soki mabele to putulu ezali na mikrobe ekoki kosala maladi epanzana mingi na esika ya kokanga yango nzela epanzana mingi te.
en-mt: One concern is that contaminated soil or dust can increase the spread of disease rather than prevent it from spreading.

sourceString: Like soap, ash is also a disinfecting agent because in contact with water, it forms an alkaline solution.
targetString: Neti sabuni, putulu ezali mpe epetolaka mpo soki esangani na mai, esalaka solution ya alkaline.
en-mt: Like soap, dust is also cleaning because when mixed with water, it forms an alkaline solution.

sourceString: WHO recommended ash or sand as alternative to soap when soap is not available.
targetString: OMS ezali kolendisa kosalela putulu to zelo na esika ya sabuni soki sabuni ezali te.
en-mt: WHO recommends using dust or sand instead of soap when soap is not available.

sourceString: Correct handwashing technique recommended by the US Centers for Disease Control  for prevention of transmission of disease includes the following steps:
targetString: Mayele ebongi ya kosokola maboko elendisami na bacentre ya kobatela maladi ya États-Unis mpo kokanga maladi nzela epanzana te ezali oyo elandi:
en-mt: Proper hand washing techniques recommended by the US Centers for Disease Control to prevent the spread of infection are as follows:

sourceString: Wet hands with warm or cold running water.
targetString: Kopolisa maboko na mai ya moto to ya malili oyo ezali kotambola.
en-mt: Polish hands with running hot or cold water.

sourceString: Running water is recommended because standing basins may be contaminated, while the temperature of the water does not seem to make a difference.
targetString: Balobaki kosalela mai ezali kotambola mpo basani oyo efandi esika moko ekoki kozala na mikrobe, mpe temperature ya mai ezali na ntina moko te.
en-mt: They said water usage is moving because toys sitting together can be contaminated, and the temperature of the water is of no consequence.

sourceString: Lather hands by rubbing them with a generous amount of soap, including the backs of hands, between fingers, and under nails.
targetString: Kopolisa maboko na kopakolaka yango sabuni mingi, ata mpe na nsima ya maboko, na kati ya misapi, mpe na nse ya manzaka.
en-mt: Polish your hands with plenty of soap, including the backs of your hands, between your fingers, and under your arms.

sourceString: Soap lifts germs from the skin, and studies show that people tend to wash their hands more thoroughly when soap is used rather than water alone.
targetString: Sabuni ebomaka mikrobe na mposo ya nzoto, mpe bolukiluki emonisi ete mbala mingi bato basokolaka maboko malamumalamu mpe ngonga molai soki soki sabuni esalemi aski kasi te soki basaleli mai yango moko.
en-mt: Soap kills germs on the skin, and research shows that people often wash their hands thoroughly and for long periods of time if the soap is used but not if the water itself is used.

sourceString: Scrub for at least 20 seconds.
targetString: Pakola sabuni ata mpo na basegonde 20.
en-mt: Apply soap for at least 20 seconds.

sourceString: Scrubbing creates friction, which helps remove germs from skin, and scrubbing for longer periods removes more germs.
targetString: Kosala bongo esalisaka na kolongola mikrobe na mposo ya nzoto, mpe kopokola ntango molai ebomaka mikrobe mingi.
en-mt: This helps to remove germs from the skin, and prolonged scrubbing kills many germs.

sourceString: Rinse well under running water.
targetString: Pangusa maboko malamu na mai oyo ezali kobima.
en-mt: Rinse hands thoroughly with running water.

sourceString: Rinsing in a basin can recontaminate hands.
targetString: Kopangusa na sani ekoki kosala ete maboko ezwa lisusu bamikrobe.
en-mt: Wiping with a bucket can lead to further infection of the hands.

sourceString: Dry with a clean towel or allow to air dry.
targetString: Kokausa na elamba ya peto to tika ekauka na mopepe.
en-mt: Dry with a clean cloth or let air dry.

sourceString: Wet and moist hands are more easily recontaminated.The most commonly missed areas are the thumb, the wrist, the areas between the fingers, and under fingernails.
targetString: Maboko oyo ezali na mai ezwaka mikrobe noki.Esika oyo mbala mingi esokolamana malamu te ezali mosapi ya monene, poignet, bisika ezali na katikati ya misapi, mpe na nse ya manzaka.
en-mt: Wet hands are more susceptible to infection.The most common areas that are not washed properly are the thumb, wrist, areas between the fingers, and under the sleeves.

sourceString: Artificial nails and chipped nail polish may harbor microorganisms.
targetString: Manzaka ya lekuta mpe biloko ya kopangusa manzaka ekoki kozala na mikrobe.
en-mt: Fake hands and hand wipes can be contaminated.

sourceString: Moisturizing lotion is often recommended to keep the hands from drying out; dry skin can lead to skin damage which can increase the risk for the transmission of infection.
targetString: Balendisaka mbala mingi kosalela mafuta ya kopakola mpona kosalisa maboko ekauka te; maboko ya kokauka ekoki kobebisa mposo ya nzoto mpe ekoki kosala moto azwa maladi kozanga mpasi.
en-mt: The use of ointment is often recommended to help prevent dry hands; dry hands can damage the skin and make a person easily infected.

sourceString: Various low-cost options can be made to facilitate hand washing where tap-water and/or soap is not available e.g. pouring water from a hanging jerrycan or gourd with suitable holes and/or using ash if needed in developing countries.In situations with limited water supply (such as schools or rural areas in developing countries), there are water-conserving solutions, such as "tippy-taps" and other low-cost options.
targetString: Mafuta mingi ya kopakola ya ntalo mingi te ekoki kosalelama mpo na kosalisa na kosokola maboko esika mai mpe/to sabuni ezali te na ndakisa kosopa mai longwa na eloko to kopo ezali na likolo mpe ezali na madusu ebongi mpe/to kosalela putulu soki esengeli na mikili ya bobola. Soki mai ezali mingi te (na ndakisa na biteyelo na bamboka na mikili ya bobola), bazali te na makoki ya kobatela mai, na ndakisa “tippy-taps” mpe lolenge mosusu oyo esengaka mbongo mingi te.
en-mt: Many inexpensive lubricating oils can be used to help wash hands where water and/or soap is not available by for example pouring water from a container or cup with a top and suitable nozzles and/or using dust if required in countries of poverty. When water is scarce (such as in schools in rural areas in developing countries), they do not have the means to conserve water, such as “tippy-taps” and other low-cost methods.

sourceString: A tippy-tap is a simple technology using a jug suspended by a rope, and a foot-operated lever to pour a small amount of water over the hands and a bar of soap.
targetString: Tippy-tap ezali mayele ya pete ya kosalela mebki oyo batye na likolo mpe bakangi na nsinga, mpe esimbani na nsinga mpona kosopa mwa mai na likolo ya maboko mpe sabuni.
en-mt: A tippy-tap is a simple technique of using a tablecloth placed on top and tied to a rope, and connected to a rope to pour some water and soap on the hands.

sourceString: Effective drying of the hands is an essential part of the hand hygiene process, but there is some debate over the most effective form of drying in public washrooms.
targetString: Kokausa maboko malamu ezali na ntina mingi mpo na kolongono ya nzoto, kasi ntembe ezali mingi na oyo etali lolenge ya malamu ya kokausa maboko na bawese ya bato mingi.
en-mt: Proper hand drying is essential for good health, but there is much controversy about the best way to dry hands in many communities.

sourceString: A growing volume of research suggests paper towels are much more hygienic than the electric hand dryers found in many washrooms.
targetString: Bolukiluki mingi ezali kosalisa ete elamba ya kosokola maboko ezali malamu mingi koleka machine ya kokausa maboko oyo ezalaka na bawese mingi.
en-mt: Many studies support that a hand wash cloth is much better than a hand dryer with many devices.

sourceString: In 2008, a study was conducted by the University of Westminster, London, and sponsored by the paper-towel industry the European Tissue Symposium, to compare the levels of hygiene offered by paper towels, warm-air hand dryers and the more modern jet-air hand dryers.
targetString: Na 2008, bolukiluki moke esalemaki na Université Westminster, na Londres, mpe oyo mosolo na yango eutaka na kompani European Tissue Symposium, oyo esalaka elamba ya kokausa maboko, mpona kososola bokeseni ya bilamba ya kokausa maboko, machine ya kokausa maboko mpe machine ya sika ya kokausa maboko.
en-mt: In 2008, a small study was conducted at the University of Westminster, London, and funded by the European Tissue Symposium, a hand dryer, to understand the differences between hand dryers, hand dryers and new dry hands.

sourceString: After washing and drying hands with the warm-air dryer, the total number of bacteria was found to increase on average on the finger pads by 194% and on the palms by 254%.
targetString: Nsima ya kosokola mpe kokausa maboko na machine ya kokausa maboko, motango ya mikrobe emataki na misapi na 194% mpe na maboko na 254%.
en-mt: After washing and drying hands in a hand dryer, bacteria counts rose on fingers by 194% and hands by 254%.

sourceString: Drying with the jet-air dryer resulted in an increase on average of the total number of bacteria on the finger pads by 42% and on the palms by 15%.
targetString: Nsima ya kosokola mpe kokausa maboko na machine ya kokausa maboko, motango ya mikrobe emataki na misapi na 42% mpe na maboko na 15%.
en-mt: After washing and drying hands in a hand dryer, bacteria counts rose on fingers by 42% and hands by 15%.

sourceString: After washing and drying hands with a paper towel, the total number of bacteria was reduced on average on the finger pads by up to 76% and on the palms by up to 77%.The scientists also carried out tests to establish whether there was the potential for cross contamination of other washroom users and the washroom environment as a result of each type of drying method.
targetString: Nsima ya kosokola mpe kokausa maboko na elamba ya kokausa maboko, motango ya mikrobe ekitaki, na misapi ekomaka 76% mpe na maboko ekomaki 77%. Bato ya siansi basalaki mpe baekzame mpona koyeba soki ete bato oyo bazalaki kosalela bawese mpe kati ya bawese epanzaki mikrobe nsima ya bandenge mingi ya kokausa maboko.
en-mt: After washing and drying the hands with a hand drying cloth, the bacterial count decreased, reaching 76% on the fingers and 77% on the hands. Scientists also tested whether people who used and inside the towels spread germs after several types of hand drying.

sourceString: The jet-air dryer, which blows air out of the unit at claimed speeds of 180 m/s (650 km/h; 400 mph), was capable of blowing micro-organisms from the hands and the unit and potentially contaminating other washroom users and the washroom environment up to 2 metres away.
targetString: Machine ya kokausa maboko, oyo ebimisaka mopepe na vitese ya 180 m/s (650 km/h; 400 mph), ekokaki kontinda bamikrobe ya mike na maboko na bisika kati na wese mpe kosimba bato misusu kati ya wese na molai ya 2 metele.
en-mt: The hand dryer, which produces air at a speed of 180 m/s (650 km/h; 400 mph), could send tiny germs by hand into the spaces between the sewers and touch other people in the sewer up to 2 meters high.

sourceString: Use of a warm-air hand dryer spread micro-organisms up to 0.25 metres from the dryer.
targetString: Kosalela machine ya kokausa maboko epanzaka bamikrobe ya mike mosika na 0,25 metele uta esika machine ezali.
en-mt: Using a hand dryer disperses microorganisms away from 0.25 meters from the machine location.

sourceString: Paper towels showed no significant spread of micro-organisms.In 2005, in a study conducted by TÜV Produkt und Umwelt, different hand drying methods were evaluated.
targetString: Bilamba ya kokausa maboko elakisaki ata moko ya bamikrobe ya mike epanzanaki. Na 2005, na bolukiuki moko esalemaki na TÜV Produkt und Umwelt, batalelaki bandenge mingi ya kokausa maboko.
en-mt: Hand drying cloths showed any of the microorganisms had broken out. In 2005, in a research conducted by TÜV Produkt und Umwelt, several methods of hand drying were examined.

sourceString: The following changes in the bacterial count after drying the hands were observed:
targetString: Bamonaki bokeseni oyo elandi na motango ya mikrobe nsima ya kokausa maboko:
en-mt: They found the following differences in bacterial counts after hand drying:

sourceString: Many different hand dryer manufacturers exist, and hand driers have been compared against drying with paper towels.
targetString: Bakompani mingi oyo esalaka bamachine ya kokausa maboko ezali, mpe bakeseni bamachine ya kokausa maboko na bilamba ya kokausa maboko.
en-mt: Many companies that make hand dryers exist, and they distinguish hand dryers from cloth dryers.

sourceString: Hand washing using hand sanitizing wipes is an alternative during traveling in the absence of soap and water.
targetString: Kokausa maboko na kosalela bilamba ya kokausa maboko ezali lolenge mosusu ya kokausa maboko na ntango ya mobembo soki sabuni na mai eza te.
en-mt: Drying hands using hand drying cloths is an alternative way to dry hands during travel if soap and water is not available.

sourceString: Alcohol-based hand sanitizer should contain at least 60% alcohol.
targetString: Bankisi ya kopetola maboko ya alcol esengeli kozala na 60% ya alcol.
en-mt: Alcohol hand sanitizers should contain 60% alcohol.

sourceString: Medical hand-washing became mandatory long after Hungarian physician Ignaz Semmelweis discovered its effectiveness (in 1846) in preventing disease in a hospital environment.
targetString: Bato bakomaki kosalela mingi bankisi ya kosokola maboko ntango mingi nsima ya ntango wana moto moko ya physique ya Hongrois Ignaz Semmelweis amonaki makasi na yango (na 1846) mpona kokanga maladi nzela epanzana te na bisika lopitalo.
en-mt: Hand sanitizers became widely used long after the Hungarian physicist Ignaz Semmelweis discovered their power (in 1846) to prevent the spread of disease in hospitals.

sourceString: There are electronic devices that provide feedback to remind hospital staff to wash their hands when they forget.
targetString: Ezali na bamachine mingi oyo ekundwelaka bato ya lepitalo na kosokola maboko soki babosani kosala yango.
en-mt: There are many machines that remind hospital staff to wash their hands if they forget to do so.

sourceString: One study has found decreased infection rates with their use.
targetString: Bolukiluki moko emonaki ete motango ya kopanza maladi ekitaki soki bazali kosalela yango.
en-mt: One study found that the rate of infection decreased with use.

sourceString: Medical hand-washing is for a minimum of 15 seconds, using generous amounts of soap and water or gel to lather and rub each part of the hands.
targetString: Bankisi ya kosokola maboko ezali mpona basegonde 15, kosalela mai mpe na sabuni mingi to mafuta ya kopakola na bisika nyonso ya loboko.
en-mt: Hand sanitizers are available for 15 seconds, using water and plenty of soap or oil to apply to all parts of the hand.

sourceString: Hands should be rubbed together with digits interlocking.
targetString: Esengeli konika maboko elongo moko na kosangisaka yango na kati ya baninga.
en-mt: The hands should be rubbed together by joining them in partners.

sourceString: If there is debris under fingernails, a bristle brush may be used to remove it.
targetString: Soki ezali na mbindo na nse ya manzaka, tokoki kosalela mwa eloko mpo na kolongola yango.
en-mt: If there is dirt under the sleeve, we can use a small amount to remove it.

sourceString: Since germs may remain in the water on the hands, it is important to rinse well and wipe dry with a clean towel.
targetString: Mpo mikrobe ekoki kotikala na mai na maboko, ezali ntina mingi kolongola mai wana mpe kopangusa yango na elamba ya peto.
en-mt: Because germs can remain in the hands, it is important to remove the water and wipe it with a clean cloth.

sourceString: After drying, the paper towel should be used to turn off the water (and open any exit door if necessary).
targetString: Na nsima ya kokausa, esengeli kosalela elamba ya kokausa mpona kokanga mai (mpe kofongola porte ya kobima soki ezali).
en-mt: After drying, a dry cloth should be used to trap water (and open the exit door if available).

sourceString: This avoids re-contaminating the hands from those surfaces.
targetString: Yango esalisaka na kopekisa maboko ezwa mikrobe na bisika wana.
en-mt: This helps prevent hands from getting infected in these areas.

sourceString: The purpose of hand-washing in the health-care setting is to remove pathogenic microorganisms ("germs") and avoid transmitting them.
targetString: Mokano ya kosokola maboko na kolongono ya nzoto ezali ya kolongola mbindo (“mikrobe”) mpe kopesa yango te na bato mosusu.
en-mt: The goal of hygienic hand washing is to remove contaminants (“germs”) and not to pass them on to others.

sourceString: The New England Journal of Medicine reports that a lack of hand-washing remains at unacceptable levels in most medical environments, with large numbers of doctors and nurses routinely forgetting to wash their hands before touching patients, thus transmitting microorganisms.
targetString: Zulunalu ya Angleterre ya sika oyo elobelaka makambo ya kimonganga elobi ete na balepital bato mingi mpenza bazosokola maboko te, mpe minganga na mafulume mingi babosanaka mbala mingi kosokola maboko liboso ya kosimba bato ya maladi, nde bongo bapesaka bango mikrobe.
en-mt: The latest British medical journal reports that in hospitals the vast majority of people do not wash their hands, and many doctors and nurses often forget to wash their hands before touching patients, thus passing on germs.

sourceString: One study showed that proper hand-washing and other simple procedures can decrease the rate of catheter-related bloodstream infections by 66 percent.The World Health Organization has published a sheet demonstrating standard hand-washing and hand-rubbing in health-care sectors.
targetString: Bolukiluki moko emonisaki ete kosokola maboko malamu mpe ndege mosusu ya pete ekoki kokitisa motango ya kopesa bato maladi ya makila na 66%. Organisation Mondiale ya Santé ebimisa mokanda moko ezali na mibeko etali kosokola maboko mpe kopangusa yango mpo na minganga.
en-mt: One study found that proper hand washing and other simple measures can reduce the incidence of blood-borne diseases by 66%. The World Health Organization has published a document with guidelines on hand washing and drying for doctors.

sourceString: The draft guidance of hand hygiene by the organization can also be found at its website for public comment.
targetString: Tokoki komona toli ya liboso ya kosokola maboko ya organization mpe ekoki mpe kozwama na siteweb na yango mpona maloba ya bato nyonso.
en-mt: We can see the organization’s first hand washing advice and can also be found on its website for public comment.

sourceString: A relevant review was conducted by Whitby et al.
targetString: Whitby na baninga na ye basalaki botaleli ya ntina.
en-mt: A critical review was conducted by Whitby et al.

sourceString: Commercial devices can measure and validate hand hygiene, if demonstration of regulatory compliance is required.
targetString: Bamachine oyo batekaka ekoki komeka mpe koloba soki maboko ezali peto, soki lolenge ya bopeto oyo basengi ekoki.
en-mt: The machines sold can measure and state if the hands are clean, if the requested level of hygiene is sufficient.

sourceString: The World Health Organization has "Five Moments" for washing hands:
targetString: Organisation Mondiale ya Santé eza na “Bangonga Mitano” mpo na kosokola maboko:
en-mt: The World Health Organization has “Five Hours” for hand washing:

sourceString: after exposure to blood/body fluids
targetString: nsima ya kosimba makila/mai ya nzoto
en-mt: after handling blood/body fluids

sourceString: before an aseptic task, and
targetString: liboso ya kosala mosala oyo ya kobatela maboko na mikrobe, mpe
en-mt: before doing this hand-proofing exercise, too

sourceString: after patient care.The addition of antiseptic chemicals to soap ("medicated" or "antimicrobial" soaps) confers killing action to a hand-washing agent.
targetString: nsima ya kosalisa moto ya maladi. Kobakisa antiseptique na sbuni (sabuni “oyo ezali na nkisi” to sabuni “ebomaka mikrobe”) esalisaka nkisi ya kosokola maboko na koboma mikrobe.
en-mt: after treating the patient. Adding an antiseptic to sbuni (“medicated” soap or “antibacterial” soap) helps the hand sanitizer disinfect.

sourceString: Such killing action may be desired prior to performing surgery or in settings in which antibiotic-resistant organisms are highly prevalent.To 'scrub' one's hands for a surgical operation, it is necessary to have a tap that can be turned on and off without touching it with the hands, some chlorhexidine or iodine wash, sterile towels for drying the hands after washing, and a sterile brush for scrubbing and another sterile instrument for cleaning under the fingernails.
targetString: Koboma mikrobe ekoki kozala ntina liboso ya kosala lipaso to na bisika oyo mikrobe ezalaka mingi mpenza. ‘Koningisa’ maboko mpo na lipaso, soki ezali ntina ezala na pompe oyo okoki kofungola mai to kokanga esengeli te basimba yango na maboko, mwa chlorhexidine to mai ya iodine, elamba ezangi mikrobe mpo na kokausa maboko nsima ya kosokola yango, mpe linyuka ezangi mikrobe mpona kolongola mbindo mpe eloko mosusu ezangi mikrobe mpona kolongola mbindo na manzaka.
en-mt: Disinfection may be necessary before surgery or in areas where bacterial infection is very high. 'Shake' hands for surgery, if necessary with a pump that you can turn on or off, some chlorhexidine or iodine water, a sterile cloth to dry hands after washing, and a sterile rag to remove dirt and another sterile material to remove dirt from hands.

sourceString: All jewelry should be removed.
targetString: Esengeli kolongola mayaka nyonso.
en-mt: All pearls should be removed.

sourceString: This procedure requires washing the hands and forearms up to the elbow, usually 2–6 minutes.
targetString: Lolende oyo esengeli kosokola maboko mpe liboso ya maboko kino katikati ya loboko, mingimingi na miniti 2-6.
en-mt: This method should scrub the palms and forearms to the middle of the palm, usually for 2-6 minutes.

sourceString: Long scrub-times (10 minutes) are not necessary.
targetString: Koweumela na konika (miniti 10) ezali ntina te.
en-mt: Prolonged grinding (10 minutes) is not necessary.

sourceString: When rinsing, water on the forearms must be prevented from running back to the hands.
targetString: Ntango ozali kopangusa, oesengeli kokanga nzela mpo mai oyo ezali na liboso ya maboko eleka te na nsima ya maboko.
en-mt: When wiping, you need to block the water from the front of the hands to the back of the hands.

sourceString: After hand-washing is completed, the hands are dried with a sterile cloth and a surgical gown is donned.
targetString: Nsima ya kosilisa kosokola maboko, esengeli kokausa maboko na elamba ezangi mikrobe mpe kolata gan ya minganga.
en-mt: After hand washing is completed, hands should be dried with a sterile cloth and a medical glove should be worn.

sourceString: To reduce the spread of germs, it is better to wash the hands or use a hand antiseptic before and after tending to a sick person.
targetString: Mpona kokanga mikrobe nzela ekabwana te, ezali malamu na kosokola maboko to kosalela antiseptique ya maboko liboso mpe nsima ya kosalisa moto ya maladi.
en-mt: To prevent germs from spreading, it is best to wash hands or use hand antiseptic before and after treating the patient.

sourceString: For control of staphylococcal infections in hospitals, it has been found that the greatest benefit from hand-cleansing came from the first 20% of washing, and that very little additional benefit was gained when hand cleansing frequency was increased beyond 35%.
targetString: Mpona kotalela maladi ya staphylocoque na balepital, emonani ete matomba ya monene ya kosokola maboko eyaki nsima ya kosokola maboko 20% ya liboso, mpe mwa litomba wana ezwamaki ntango bazalaki kosokola maboko na 35%.
en-mt: For the assessment of staphylococcal infections in hospitals, it appears that the greatest benefits of hand washing came after the first 20% of hands were washed, and this small benefit was found when hands were washed at 35%.

sourceString: Washing with plain soap results in more than triple the rate of bacterial infectious disease transmitted to food as compared to washing with antibacterial soap.Comparing hand-rubbing with alcohol-based solution with hand washing with antibacterial soap for a median time of 30 seconds each showed that the alcohol hand-rubbing reduced bacterial contamination 26% more than the antibacterial soap.
targetString: Kosokola na sabuni ekolisaka motango ya kopanza mikrobe ya maladi mbala misato na bilei soki tokokanisi yango na kosokola maboko na sabuni oyo ezali na nkisi ya koboma mikrobe. Bokeseni ya kopetola maboko na nkisi oyo ezali na alcol, kosokola maboko na sabuni ezali na nkisi ya koboma mikrobe na basegonde 30 ekitisaka motango ya kopanza mikrobe na 26% koleka soki basabuni ezali na nkisi ya koboma mikrobe.
en-mt: Washing with soap triples the rate of spreading pathogens in food compared to washing hands with disinfectant soap. A combination of alcohol-based hand sanitizer, hand washing with disinfectant soap for 30 seconds reduces the spread of germs by 26% compared to if the soaps contain disinfectant.

sourceString: But soap and water is more effective than alcohol-based hand rubs for reducing H1N1 influenza A virus and Clostridium difficile spores from hands.Interventions to improve hand hygiene in healthcare settings can involve education for staff on hand washing, increasing the availability of alcohol-based hand rub, and written and verbal reminders to staff.
targetString: Kasi sabuni na mai ezali makasi mingi koleka bankisi oyo ezali na alcol ya kopakola mpona kokotisa virisi A ya grippe H1N1 mpe clostridiume difficile spores na maboko. Milende ya kobongisa mosala kopetola maboko na balopitalo ekoki kosenga koteya bato ya mosala na kosokola maboko, kosala ete bato bazali na bankisi mingi ya kopetola maboko ezali na alcol, mpe makundoli ya kokoma mpe ya monoko na bato ya mosala.
en-mt: But soap and water are much more effective than alcohol-based sprays at getting H1N1 influenza A virus and Clostridium difficile spores into the hands. Efforts to improve performance hand hygiene in hospitals may involve educating staff in hand hygiene, ensuring availability of most alcohol-based hand sanitizers, and written and verbal reminders to staff.

sourceString: There is a need for more research into which of these interventions are most effective in different healthcare settings.
targetString: Ezali na bolukiluki mingi mpo na koyeba nini ya mayele oyo ekosalisa na bisika mingi mpo na kolongono ya nzoto.
en-mt: There is a lot of research into which of these strategies will help in many areas of health.

sourceString: In developing countries, hand washing with soap is recognized as a cost-effective, essential tool for achieving good health, and even good nutrition.
targetString: Emonani ete na mikili ya bobola, kosokola maboko na sabuni ezali na ntalo malamu, ntina mingi mpo na kozala nzoto kolongono, mpe nkutu ntina mpo na kolya bilei ya malamu.
en-mt: It turns out that in developing countries, hand washing with soap is affordable, essential to good health, and even essential to a healthy diet.

sourceString: However, a lack of reliable water supply, soap or hand washing facilities in people's homes, at schools and at the workplace make it a challenge to achieve universal hand washing behaviors.
targetString: Kasi, kozanga mai, sabuni, bisika ya kosokola maboko na ndako, na biteyelo mpe na bisika ya mosala ezali kosala ete ezala mpasi mpo bato nyonso bakoma na ezaleli ya kosokola maboko.
en-mt: However, the lack of water, soap, hand washing facilities at home, schools and workplaces makes it difficult for everyone to adopt hand washing habits.

sourceString: For example, in most of rural Africa hand washing taps close to every private or public toilet are scarce, even though cheap options exist to build hand washing stations.
targetString: Na ndakisa, na bamboka mingi ya Afrika bisika ya kosokola maboko pene ya bawese ya bato to ya piblik ezali mingi te, ata ete maponi ya ntalo moke ezali mpona kosala bisika ya kosokola maboko.
en-mt: For example, in many African countries there are few hand washing facilities near private or public toilets, although there are cheaper options for hand washing facilities.

sourceString: However, low hand washing rates rather can also be the result of engrained habits rather than due to a lack of soap or water.
targetString: Kasi, kosokola maboko mbala mingi te ekoki kozala ezaleli moko oyo bato bamesana na yango kasi ezali te mpo bazangi sabuni na mai.
en-mt: However, infrequent hand washing may be a habit but not a lack of soap and water.

sourceString: The promotion and advocacy of hand washing with soap can influence policy decisions, raise awareness about the benefits of hand washing and lead to long-term behavior change of the population.
targetString: Kotombola mpe kolendisa kosokola maboko na sabuni ekoki kopusa kopona mibeko, pusa maloba ya ntina ya kosokola maboko mpe kosalisa bato babongola mpenza bizaleli na bango.
en-mt: Promoting and encouraging hand washing with soap can influence policy choices, push key hand-washing slogans and help people radically change their behaviour.

sourceString: For this to work effectively, monitoring and evaluation are necessary.
targetString: Mpo esalama malamu, kolandela mpe botaleli ezali ntina mingi.
en-mt: For it to be done properly, monitoring and evaluation is essential.

sourceString: A systematic review of 70 studies found that community-based approaches are effective at increasing hand washing in LMICs, while social marketing campaigns are less effective.One example for hand washing promotion in schools is the "Three Star Approach" by UNICEF that encourages schools to take simple, inexpensive steps to ensure that students wash their hands with soap, among other hygienic requirements.
targetString: Kotalela bolukiluki 70 emonisaki ete kolendisa ezaleli ya kosokola maboko na bamboka ezali ntina mingi na LMICs, kasi kotelemela kopanza maloba ezali kosapema mingi te. Ndakisa moko ya kolendisa kosokola maboko na biteyelo "Mayele Misato" ya UNICEF oyo azali kolendisa biteyelo basala makambo ya pete, ya ntalo mingi te oyo ekokoki kosala bana ya kelasi basokola maboko na sabuni, kati ya bibongiseli mosusu mpona bopeto.
en-mt: A review of 70 studies revealed that promoting hand washing behavior in rural areas is particularly important in LMICs, but resistance to spreading rumors is less persuasive. An example of encouraging hand washing in schools is UNICEF's "Three Strategies" which encourages schools to develop simple, inexpensive activities that can encourage school children to wash their hands with soap, among other hygiene measures.

sourceString: When minimum standards are achieved, schools can move from one to ultimately three stars.
targetString: Soki biteyelo elongi kokotisa mwa bizaleli malamu, bakoki sikoyo koleka na oyo ya makasi.
en-mt: If schools succeed in instilling some positive values, they can now move on to stronger ones.

sourceString: Building hand washing stations can be a part of hand washing promotion campaigns that are carried out in order to reduce diseases and child mortality.
targetString: Kotonga bisika ya kosokola maboko ekoki kozala na kati ya makambo ya kotambola kopanza sango ya kosokola maboko oyo ezali kosalema mpo na kokitisa bokono mpe kufa ya bana.
en-mt: Construction of hand washing facilities can be included in the campaign to spread the word about hand washing that is being done to reduce child morbidity and mortality.

sourceString: Global Hand washing Day is another example of an awareness-raising campaign that is trying to achieve behavior change.As a result of the 2019-20 coronavirus pandemic, UNICEF promoted the adoption of a handwashing emoji.
targetString: Mokolo ya kosokola maboko mpo na bato nyonso ezali ndakisa mosusu ya kapanza sango oyo ezali kosalisa bato na kobongola bizaleli. Ndenge maladi mabe ya coronavirisi 2019-20 ebimi, UNICEF azali kolendisa kobimisa emoji ya bosokoli maboko.
en-mt: A public hand washing day is another example of a campaign that is helping people change behavior. As the 2019-20 coronavirus pandemic emerges, UNICEF is encouraging the release of a hand washing emoji.

sourceString: Few studies have considered the overall cost effectiveness of hand washing in developing countries in relationship to DALYs averted.
targetString: Bolukiluki mosusu etaleli motuya nyonso ya kosokola maboko na mikili ya bobola na oyo etali likebisi ya DALYs.
en-mt: Other research considers the total cost of hand washing in developing countries in terms of DALYs warning.

sourceString: However, one review suggests that promoting hand washing with soap is significantly more cost-effective than other water and sanitation interventions.
targetString: Kasi, botaleli moko elakisi ete kolendisa kosokola maboko na sabuni esengaka mbongo mingi te soki tokokanisi yango na banzela mosusu na ndakisa mai mpe mayele mosusu ya kotya bopeto.
en-mt: However, one analysis shows that promoting hand washing with soap is cost-effective compared to other options such as water and other sanitation methods.

sourceString: The importance of hand washing for human health – particularly for people in vulnerable circumstances like mothers who had just given birth or wounded soldiers in hospitals – was first recognized in the mid 19th century by two pioneers of hand hygiene: the Hungarian physician Ignaz Semmelweis who worked in Vienna, Austria and Florence Nightingale, the English "founder of modern nursing".
targetString: Ntina ya kosokola maboko mpo na kolongono ya nzoto ya mingimingi mpo na bato oyo baza na likama na ndakisa bamama oyo bauti kobota to basoda bazoki oyo bazali na balopitalo – bandimaki yango na mbala ya liboso na katikati ya siekle ya 19 na bato mibale oyo babandisaki mosala ya kosokola maboko: Ignaz Semmelweis, monganga ya Hongrois, oyo asalaki na Vienne, na Autriche mpe Florence Nightingale, moto ya Angleterre “oyo abandaki mosala ya mafulume".
en-mt: The importance of hand washing for health especially for vulnerable people such as new mothers or wounded soldiers in hospitals – was first recognized in the mid-19th century by two pioneers of hand washing: Ignaz Semmelweis, a Hungarian physician, who worked in Vienna, Austria and Florence Nightingale, an Englishwoman “who pioneered nursing”.

sourceString: At that time most people still believed that infections were caused by foul odors called miasmas.
targetString: Na ntango wana, bato mingi bazalaki kondima kaka ete maladi euta na bansolo ya mabe oyo babengaki miasme.
en-mt: At the time, most people simply believed that illness was caused by foul smells called miasms.

sourceString: In the 1980s, foodborne outbreaks and healthcare-associated infections led the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to more actively promote hand hygiene as an important way to prevent the spread of infection.
targetString: Na mibu 1980, kobima ya maladi euti na bilei mpe ya maladi euti na kosalisa bato ya maladi, epusaki ba centre ya États-Unis oyo ebundisaka maladi mpe ebatelaka yango na kolendisa mingi lisusu bopeto ya maboko mpe koloba ete ezali ntina mingi mpo na kokanga maladi nzela epanzana te.
en-mt: In the 1980s, outbreaks of foodborne illness and patient care prompted the US centers of disease control and control to further promote hand hygiene and tout its importance in disease containment the road does not break.

sourceString: The outbreak of swine flu in 2009 and the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020 led to increased awareness in many countries of the importance of washing hands with soap to protect oneself from such infectious diseases.
targetString: Kobima ya grippe ya bangulu na 2009 mpe ya maladi mabe ya COVID-19 na 2020, epusi bato ya mikili mingi batya likebi na ntina ya kosokola maboko na sabuni mpona komitabela na maladi mabe ya ndenge wana.
en-mt: The outbreak of swine flu in 2009 and the pandemic of COVID-19 in 2020, has prompted international attention to the importance of washing hands with soap to protect against such pandemics.

sourceString: For example, posters with "correct hand washing techniques" were hung up next to hand washing sinks in public toilets and in the toilets of office buildings and airports in Germany.
targetString: Na ndakisa, bapankarte bakoma "lolenge ya malamu ya kosokola maboko" batyaki yango pene ya bisika ya kosokola maboko ya bawese ya bato nyonso mpe na bawese ya babiro mpe ba aeroport na Allemagne.
en-mt: For example, signs with the words "good hand washing practices" were placed near hand washing facilities in public toilets and at office and airport toilets in Germany.

sourceString: The phrase "washing one's hands of" something, means declaring one's unwillingness to take responsibility for the thing or share complicity in it.
targetString: Maloba "kosokola maboko ya moto na" likambo moko, elingi koloba koboya kozwa mokumba mpona eloko moko to koboya kosangana na yango.
en-mt: The words "to wash one's hands in" something, means to refuse to take responsibility for something or to refuse to participate in it.

sourceString: It originates from the bible passage in Matthew where Pontius Pilate washed his hands of the decision to crucify Jesus Christ, but has become a phrase with a much wider usage in some English communities.
targetString: Ebimelaki na eteni ya biblia esika Matayo akoma ete Ponte Pilato asokolaki maboko na ekateli ya kobaka Yesu Klisto na ekulusu, kasi ekoma maloba oyo bato basalelaka mingi na bamboka oyo bato balobaka Anglais.
en-mt: It appeared in the part of the bible where Matthew records that Pontius Pilate washed his hands of the decision to crucify Jesus Christ, but it has become common saying in English-speaking countries.

sourceString: In Shakespeare's Macbeth, Lady Macbeth begins to compulsively wash her hands in an attempt to cleanse an imagined stain, representing her guilty conscience regarding crimes she had committed and induced her husband to commit.
targetString: Na lisapo ya Shakespeare ebengami Macbeth, Mama Macbeth abandi kosokola maboko oyo esengami mpo na kopetola mbindo oyo ezalaki kaka na makanisi, oyo elakisi bososoli na ye ya mabe na makambo mabe ya kobuka mibeko oyo ye asalaki mpe apusaki mobali na ye na kosala.
en-mt: In Shakespeare's play Macbeth, Mother Macbeth begins the required washing of hands to cleanse the uncleanness that was only in the mind, which shows her wrong understanding of the crimes she committed and incited her husband to commit.

sourceString: It has also been found that people, after having recalled or contemplated unethical acts, tend to wash hands more often than others, and tend to value hand washing equipment more.
targetString: Emonani ete nsima ya kokundwela bato bizaleli ya mabe to soki bango moko bakaniseli yango, mbala mingi bakosokola maboko koleka bato mosusu, mpe bazali na matondo mingi na biloko esalisaka na kosokola maboko.
en-mt: It turns out that after being reminded of bad behavior or if they think about it themselves, they are more likely to wash their hands than others, and they are more grateful for hand sanitizers.

sourceString: Furthermore, those who are allowed to wash their hands after such a contemplation are less likely to engage in other "cleansing" compensatory actions, such as volunteering.
targetString: Lisusu, bato oyo bapesi bango nzela ya kosokola maboko nsima ya makanisi wana mingi basanganaka lisusu te na makambo misusu ya makasi ya “bopeto,” na ndakisa kosala mosala ya komipesa.
en-mt: Furthermore, people who are allowed to wash their hands after these considerations often no longer participate in other strict “cleanliness” activities, such as volunteering.

sourceString: Religions prescribe hand washing for both hygienic and symbolic purposes.Symbolic hand washing, using water but no soap to wash hands, is a part of ritual hand washing featured in many religions, including Bahá'í Faith, Hinduism, tevilah and netilat yadayim in Judaism, Lavabo in Christianity, and Wudhu in Islam.Religions also prescribe hygienic hand washing, especially after certain actions.
targetString: Na losambo, mangomba esengaka kosokola maboko mpo na bopeto mpe ya elilingi.
