Kosokola maboko ya elilingi, oyo basalelaka mai kasi sabuni te mpo na kosokola maboko, ezali bindimeli ya kosokola maboko na mangomba mingi, na ndakisa na lingomba ya Bahá'í, ya Hindou, ya tevilah mpe na netilat yadayim na lingomba ya Bayuda, Lavabo na lingomba ya Boklisto mpe Wudhu na lingomba ya ba Mizilma. Mangomba esengaka mpe bato basokola maboko mpo na bopeto, mingimingi nsima ya kosala makambo moko boye.
en-mt: In worship, churches require hand washing for cleanliness and symbolism. Symbolic hand washing, in which water and not soap is used to wash the hands, is a hand washing belief in many religions, such as the Bahá'í, Hindu, tevilah and netilat yadayim in Judaism, Lavabo na the Christian religion and Wudhu in the Muslim religion. Religions also require people to wash their hands for hygiene, especially after certain activities.

sourceString: Hinduism, Judaism and Islam mandate washing of hands after using the toilet.
targetString: Lingomba ya Hindu, ya Bayuda mpe ya ba Mizilma batya mobeko ete bato basokola maboko nsima ya kokende na wese.
en-mt: Hinduism, Judaism, and Islam require hand washing after going to the toilet.

sourceString: And, Hinduism, Buddhism, Sikhism, Judaism and Islam mandate washing of hands before and after every meal.
targetString: Lisusu, lingomba ya Hindu, ya Bouddha, ya Sikhi, ya Bayuda mpe ya Mizilma batya mobeko bato basokola maboko liboso mpe nsima ya kolya.
en-mt: In addition, Hinduism, Buddhism, Sikhism, Judaism, and Islam require hand washing before and after meals.

sourceString: Workplace hazard controls for COVID-19
targetString: Biloko ya komibatela na makama na mosala COVID-19
en-mt: Occupational safety equipment COVID-1

sourceString: Workplace hazard controls for COVID-19 are the application of occupational safety and health methodologies for hazard controls to the prevention of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19).
targetString: Biloko ya komibatela na mosala mpo na COVID-19 eza kosalela mayele etali libateli mpe kolongono ya nzoto mpo na kokanga nzela ete maladi ya coronavirisi 2019 (COVID-19) epanzana te.
en-mt: Occupational protective equipment for COVID-19 is using safety and health strategies to prevent the spread of the coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19).

sourceString: The proper hazard controls in the workplace depend on the worksite and job task, based on a risk assessment of sources of exposure, disease severity in the community, and risk factors of individual workers who may be vulnerable to contracting COVID-19.
targetString: Lolenge ya malamu ya komibatela na mosala etaleli esika mosala esalemaka mpe mosala yango, etaleli makama ya komitika na makambo ya makama, ndenge maladi ekoti esika bofandi, mpe makama oyo bato ya mosala bakoki kozala na risque ya kozwa maladi ya COVID-19.
en-mt: The best way to protect yourself in the workplace depends on the workplace and the job, the risks of exposure to hazardous conditions, the prevalence of disease in your area, and the risks that workers may be exposed to.

sourceString: According to the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), lower exposure risk jobs have minimal occupational contact with the public and other coworkers, for which basic infection prevention measures are recommended, including hand washing, encouraging workers to stay home if they are sick, respiratory etiquette, and maintaining routine cleaning and disinfecting of the work environment.
targetString: Na kotalela ministre ya libateli mpe santé ya États-Unis (OSHA), mosala eza na makama moke eza mosala oyo esengaka kokutana na bato mosusu mpe baninga ya mosala mingi te, oyo esengaka kosalela mayele ya ntina ya libateli, na ndakisa kosokola maboko, kolendisa bato ya mosala na kotikala na ndako soki bazobela, babelaka maladi ya mpema, mpe kozala na ezaleli ya kotya bopeto mpe ya kopetola esika ya mosala.
en-mt: According to the U.S. Department of Health and Safety (OSHA), low-risk work is work that requires minimal contact with other people and co-workers, which requires the use of basic safety techniques, such as hand washing, reinforcement employees by staying home if they are sick, suffering from respiratory diseases, and by maintaining cleanliness and hygiene in the workplace.

sourceString: Medium exposure risk jobs include those that require frequent or close contact with people who are not known or suspected with COVID-19, but may be infected due to ongoing community transmission or international travel.
targetString: Mosala ya likama ya katikati eza misala oyo esengaka kokutana mbala mingi to na pembeni na bato oyo oyebi to baoyo bakoki kozala na COVID-19, kasi bakoki kozala na maladi mpo bakutanaka na bato mingi to basalaka mibembo na mikili mingi.
en-mt: Moderate risk occupation is occupation that requires frequent or close contact with people you know or may have COVID-19, but who may become ill because of extensive contact or international travel.

sourceString: This includes workers who have contact with the general public such as in schools, high-population-density work environments, and some high-volume retail settings.
targetString: Yango etali bato ya mosala oyo bakutanaka na bato mingi na ndakisa na biteyelo, na bisika ya mosala oyo bato bazalaka mingi, mpe na bisika mosusu oyo bato bazalaka mingi.
en-mt: This applies to professionals who encounter many people such as schools, busy workplaces, and other public places.

sourceString: Hazard controls for this group, in addition to basic infection prevention measures, include ventilation using high-efficiency air filters, sneeze guards, and having personal protective equipment available in case a person with COVID-19 is encountered.
targetString: Komibatela na makama na etuluku oyo, longola makambo bato nyonso basalaka mpo na komibatela na maladi, esengeli kosalela ventillateur oyo eza na bafiltre ya makasi mpenza, komibatela liboso ya kosala itche, mpe kozala na bisaleli ya komibatela soki okutani na moto oyo aza na maladi ya COVID-19.
en-mt: Safety precautions in this group, in addition to what everyone else does to protect themselves from illness, include using a ventilator with very tight filters, protecting yourself before itching, and having personal protective equipment if you come across someone with COVID-1

sourceString: OSHA considers healthcare and mortuary workers exposed to known or suspected person with COVID-19 to be at high exposure risk, which increases to very high exposure risk if workers perform aerosol-generating procedures on, or collect or handle specimens from, known or suspected person with COVID-19.
targetString: OSHA etalelaka minganga mpe bato basalaka na morgue ete baza bato oyo bayebani to likoki ezali bakutana na moto aza na COVID-19 baza na likama ya monene, mpe esalaka ete bato oyo basalaka misala ya aerosol to basimbaka to bazwaka ba échantillon, ya bato oyo baza na COVID-19 to baoyo bakoki kozala na yango.
en-mt: OSHA considers physicians and morgue personnel who are known or likely to have contact with someone with COVID-19 to be at high risk, and makes it necessary for persons who perform aerosol operations or handle or collect samples, of persons who are with COVID-19 or those who may have it.

sourceString: Hazard controls appropriate for these workers include engineering controls such as negative pressure ventilation rooms, and personal protective equipment appropriate to the job task.
targetString: Komibatela malamu na makama mpo na bato yo basalaka misala oyo ekoki kozala komibatela na bandako oyo eza na mopepe ya mabe ya ventillateur, mpe kozala na bilamba ya malamu ya libateli mpo na mosala wana.
en-mt: Proper protection from hazards for people you do these jobs may include protecting yourself from ventilated buildings, and having the right protective clothing for that job.

sourceString: COVID-19 outbreaks can have several effects within the workplace.
targetString: Kobima ya COVID-19 ekoki kozala na makama mingi na esika ya mosala.
en-mt: The outbreak of COVID-19 can be very dangerous in the workplace.

sourceString: Workers may be absent from work due to becoming sick, needing to care for others, or from fear of possible exposure.
targetString: Bato ya mosala bakoki kozala te na mosala mpo bazobela, bazobatela bato mosusu, to bazobanga mbala mosusu bakokutana na moko aza na maladi wana.
en-mt: Workers may not be at work because they are sick, caring for others, or afraid of meeting someone with the disease.

sourceString: Patterns of commerce may change, both in terms of what goods are demanded, and the means of acquiring these goods (such as shopping at off-peak hours or through delivery or drive-through services).
targetString: Lolenge ya kosala mombongo ekoki kobongwana, ekoki kozala na biloko bato bazoluka kosomba, mpe ndenge ya kozwa biloko yango (na ndakisa kosomba na ntango bato baza mingi to na nzela ya misala ya livraison à domicile).
en-mt: The nature of the transaction may change, there may be products that people are looking to buy, and the availability of those products (such as buying during peak hours or through home delivery services).

sourceString: Lastly, shipments of items from geographic areas severely affected by COVID-19 may be interrupted.An infectious disease preparedness and response plan can be used to guide protective actions.
targetString: Ya nsuka, bakoki kopekisa kokende kotika biloko na bisika oyo maladi ya COVID-19 eza mingi. Komibongisa na maladi ekoki kosalisa na koyeba nini tokosala mpo na komibatela.
en-mt: Finally, drop-offs in high-risk areas may be restricted. Preparing for illness can help determine what we will do to protect ourselves.

sourceString: Plans address the levels of risk associated with various worksites and job tasks, including sources of exposure, risk factors arising from home and community settings, and risk factors of individual workers such as old age or chronic medical conditions.
targetString: Baplan ezolobela nivo ya likama oyo eza na bisika ya mosala mpe misala, ata mpe bato oyo okokutana na bango, makambo ezosala makama ekoma mingi na ndako mpe bisika mosusu, mpe makama oyo bato ya mosala na ndakisa mibange to bato oyo baza na maladi esilaka te baza na yango.
en-mt: The plans address the level of risk in workplaces and activities, including the people you will come into contact with, the increased risk factors in the home and elsewhere, and the chronic risks faced by workers such as the elderly or the sick they have it.

sourceString: They also outline controls necessary to address those risks, and contingency plans for situations that may arise as a result of outbreaks.
targetString: Ezolobela mpe ndenge ya kolandela mpo na kobongisa makama wana, mpe lolenge ya kobongisa makambo oyo ekoki kobima mpo na maladi oyo.
en-mt: It also discusses how to monitor for correcting these risks, and how to improve the consequences of this disease.

sourceString: Infectious disease preparedness and response plans may be subject to national or subnational recommendations.
targetString: Komibongisa na maladi mabe mpe makambo ya kosala mpo na kobundisa yango ekosalema na kolanda mibeko ya ekolo to ya mboka.
en-mt: Epidemic preparedness and response measures shall be implemented in accordance with national or local legislation.

sourceString: Objectives for response to an outbreak include reducing transmission among staff, protecting people who are at higher risk for adverse health complications, maintaining business operations, and minimizing adverse effects on other entities in their supply chains.
targetString: Lolenge malamu ya kobundisa yango etali makambo mpo na maladi oyo etali na ndakisa kokitisa ndenge ekoki kopanzana kati ya bato ya mosala, kobatela bato oyo baza na likama monene mpo baza na maladi ya kala, kokoba kosala mosala, mpe kosala makambo mpo ebebisa te mosala ya bakompani mosusu oyo basalaka elongo na bino.
en-mt: The best way to combat it depends on issues for the disease related to for example reducing the likelihood of it spreading among the workforce, protecting people at high risk because they have pre-existing conditions, continuing to work, and taking steps to avoid disrupting the work of other companies that work with you.

sourceString: The disease severity in the community where the business is located affects the responses taken.
targetString: Makambo bokosala ekotalela ndenge oyo maladi yango ekoti na bongo na bino.
en-mt: Your actions will depend on how the disease has entered your brain.

sourceString: The hierarchy of hazard controls is a framework widely used in occupational safety and health to group hazard controls by effectiveness.
targetString: Koyeba ndenge moto na moto akosala makambo mpo na komibatela na makama eza mwango endimami mpo na kobatela bato ya mosala mpe kolongono ya nzoto ya bato mingi na kotalela bokasi na yango.
en-mt: Individual safety precautions are an accepted method of protecting workers and the health of many people depending on their effectiveness.

sourceString: Where COVID-19 hazards cannot be eliminated, the most effective controls are engineering controls, followed by administrative controls, and lastly personal protective equipment.
targetString: Bisika bakoki kolongola te makama ya COVID-19, lolenge ya malamu koleka ya kobundisa yango eza kotalelaka ba mashine, nsima kotalela ya bakonzi, mpe na nsuka kopesa moto na moko bisaleli ebongi mpo na komibatela.
en-mt: Where the risks of COVID-19 cannot be eliminated, the best way to combat them is to assess machinery, then assess authorities, and finally provide individuals with appropriate protective equipment.

sourceString: Engineering controls involve isolating employees from work-related hazards without relying on worker behavior, and can be the most cost-effective solution to implement.
targetString: Kotalela ba mashine elakisi kotya bato ya mosala mosika na makama ya mosala kozanga kobebisa bizaleli malamu ya mosala, mpe ekoki kozala lolenge ya malamu ya kosala makambo.
en-mt: Checking machines means keeping workers away from work hazards without compromising work ethic, and can be a better way of doing things.

sourceString: Administrative controls are changes in work policy or procedures that require action by the worker or employer.
targetString: Botaleli ya bakonzi ezali kobongola lolenge ya kosala mosala oyo ezosenga patron to moto ya mosala abongola ndenge na ye ya kosala.
en-mt: Executive review is a change in the way work is done that requires the employer or employee to change their way of doing things.

sourceString: Personal protective equipment (PPE) is considered less effective than engineering and administrative controls, but can help prevent some exposures.
targetString: Bisaleli ya komibatela (PPE) eza makasi mingi te soki tokokanisi yango na botaleli ya ba mashine to ya bakonzi, kasi ekoki kosalisa na kokima makama mosusu.
en-mt: Personal protective equipment (PPE) is less powerful than mechanical or official checks, but it can help avoid certain hazards.

sourceString: All types of PPE must be selected based upon the hazard to the worker, properly fitted as applicable (e.g., respirators), consistently and properly worn, regularly inspected, maintained, and replaced, as necessary, and properly removed, cleaned, and stored or disposed of to avoid contamination.
targetString: Bosengeli kopona lolenge nyonso ya PPE na kotalela makama oyo eza mpo na moto ya mosala, soki ebongi mpenza (na ndakisa biloko esalisaka na kopema), kolata yango malamu mpe ntango nyonso, kobatela yango, mpe kotya ya sika, soki esengami, mpe kolongola yango malamu, kosokola yango, kobongisa to kobwaka yango mpo emema maladi te.
en-mt: You should select each type of PPE based on the hazards to the worker, if appropriate (such as respirators), wear it properly and regularly, maintain it, and replace it, if necessary, and remove it properly, wash, prepare or dispose of them to prevent disease.

sourceString: According to the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), lower exposure risk jobs have minimal occupational contact with the public and other coworkers.
targetString: Na kotalela ministere ya libateli mpe kolongono ya nzoto (OSHA), makama ya moke na mosala eza oyo esengaka kokutana na bato mingi te mpe baninga ya mosala mingi te.
en-mt: According to the Department of Health and Safety (OSHA), the least hazardous occupational hazards are those that require minimal contact with people and colleagues.

sourceString: Basic infection prevention measures recommended for all workplaces include frequent and thorough hand washing, encouraging workers to stay home if they are sick, respiratory etiquette including covering coughs and sneezes, providing tissues and trash receptacles, preparing for telecommuting or staggered shifts if needed, discouraging workers from using others' tools and equipment, and maintaining routine cleaning and disinfecting of the work environment.
targetString: Lolenge ya malamu ya komibatela mpo maladi epanzana te na mosala oyo endimami eza kosokola maboko mbala na mbala, kolendisa bato ya mosala na kotikala na ndako soki bazobela, soki babelaka maladi ya mpema, kozipa monoko to zolo soki bakosoli to basali itche, kozala bilamba ya kopangusa mpe esika ya kobwaka yango, kobongisa bisaleli ya kosolola na mosika to mosusu soki eza ntina kopekisa bato ya mosala basalela bisaleli ya bato mosusu, mpe kobatela bizaleli ya kotya bopeto mpe kopetola esika ya mosala.
en-mt: The best way to protect yourself from the spread of disease in the approved workplace is to wash your hands frequently, encourage workers to stay home if they are sick, if they have a respiratory illness, cover your mouth or nose if they sneeze or itch, wear clothing cleaning and disposal, repairing remote or other communication equipment if necessary to prevent workers from using other people's equipment, and maintaining cleanliness and hygiene in the workplace.

sourceString: Prompt identification and isolation of potentially infectious individuals is a critical step in protecting workers, customers, visitors, and others at a worksite.
targetString: Koyeba noki bato oyo bakoki kozala na maladi mpe kotya bango mosika na basusu eza lolenge ya malamu mingi ya kobatela bato ya mosala, basombi, bapaya, mpe bato mosusu na esika ya mosala.
en-mt: Early identification and isolation of potentially ill individuals is the most effective way to protect employees, shoppers, guests, and others in the workplace.

sourceString: The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends that employees who have symptoms of acute respiratory illness are to stay home until they are free of fever, signs of a fever, and any other symptoms for at least 24 hours without the use of fever-reducing or other symptom-altering medicines, and that sick leave policies are flexible, permit employees to stay home to care for a sick family member, and that employees are aware of these policies.
targetString: Ba centre ya kobundisa maladi mabe mpe kobatela bato na yango (CDC) ya États-Unis ezolendisa ete bato ya mosala oyo baza na bilembo ya maladi ya makasi ya mpema batikala na ndako kino fievre, bilembo ya fievre, mpe bilembo mosusu ekosila ata na bangonga 24 kozanga kosala nkisi ya kokitisa fievre to nkisi mosusu mpo na bilembo mosusu, mpe batya mibeko malamu mpo na congé ya malamu, kopesa bato ya mosala nzela ya kotikala na ndako mpo na kobatela bato ya libota oyo bazobela, mpe ete bato ya mosala basengeli koyeba mibeko wana.
en-mt: The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) encourages workers with symptoms of severe respiratory illness to stay home until fever, febrile symptoms, and other symptoms resolve even within hours 24 failure to develop fever reducers or other treatments for certain symptoms, and establish better policies for effective leave, allowing staff to stay home to care for sick family members, and that staff should be aware these rules.

sourceString: According to OSHA, medium exposure risk jobs include those that require frequent or close contact within six feet (1.8 m) of people who are not known or suspected COVID-19 patients, but may be infected with SARS-CoV-2 due to ongoing community transmission around the business location, or because the individual has recent international travel to a location with widespread COVID-19 transmission.
targetString: Na kotalela OSHA, likama ya katikati na mosala etali makambo neti bato oyo bakutanaka na bato mingi to bazalaka pene ya bametre 1,8 ya bato oyo baza na COVID-19 to oyo bazokanisa bakoki kozala na yango, kasi bakoki kozwa SARS-CoV-2 mpo maladi yango ezopanza mingi na esika bofandi na esika ya mosala, to mpo bato basalaki mobembo kala te na mikili mosusu esika COVID-19 ezopanzana mingi.
en-mt: According to OSHA, a moderate occupational hazard refers to situations such as people who have close contact with or are within 1.8 meters of people who have COVID-19 or are suspected of having it, but may be infected with SARS-CoV-2 because the disease is more prevalent in the workplace, or because people have recently traveled to other countries where COVID-19 is more prevalent.

sourceString: These include workers who have contact with the general public such as in schools, high-population-density work environments, and some high-volume retail settings.Engineering controls for this and higher risk groups include installing high-efficiency air filters, increasing ventilation rates, installing physical barriers such as clear plastic sneeze guards, and installing a drive-through window for customer service.Administrative controls for this and higher risk groups include encouraging sick workers to stay at home, replacing face-to-face meetings with virtual communications, establishing staggered shifts, discontinuing nonessential travel to locations with ongoing COVID-19 outbreaks, developing emergency communications plans including a forum for answering workers’ concerns, providing workers with up-to-date education and training on COVID-19 risk factors and protective behaviors, training workers who need to use protecting clothing and equipment how to use it, providing resources and a work environment that promotes personal hygiene, requiring regular hand washing, limiting customers' and the public's access to the worksite, and posting signage about hand washing and other COVID-19 protective measures.Depending on the work task, workers with at least medium exposure risk may need to wear personal protective equipment including some combination of gloves, a gown, a face shield or face mask, or goggles.
targetString: Etali bato ya mosala oyo bakutanaka na bato ya ndenge na ndenge na ndakisa na biteyelo, na esika ya mosala oyo bato bazalaka mingi mpenza, mpe na bisika mosusu ya bato mingi. Kobatela ya ba mashine mpo na bato ya boye esengaka kotya bafiltre ya makasi ya mopepe, kosala ete ba ventilateur ebaluka makasi, kotya biloko ekabolaka bato neti biloko oyo elekisaka te mopepe ya itche, mpe kotya madesu na fenetre mpo na baoyo bazoyamba bakiliya. Libateli ya bakonzi mpo na bituluku ya likama mingi ezosenga kolendisa bato ya mosala oyo bazobela batikala na ndako, kosala makita na internet na esika ya kozala na esika moko, kotya mibeko mpo na kolongola mibembo ezangi ntina na bisika oyo COVID-19 ezali, kosala mayele ya kosolola ata mpe ba forume mpo na kolandela mikakatano ya bato ya mosala, kopesa bato ya mosala bansango ya sika mpe formation ebongi mpo na makama ya COVID-19 mpe makambo ya kosala mpo na komibatela, kopesa formation na bato ya mosala oyo basengeli kosalela bilamba ya komibatela mpe koyebisa bango ndenge ya kosalela yango, kopesa bango bisaleli mpe basala na esika oyo eza peto, ezosenga kosokola maboko mbala na mbala, kosala ete bakiliya na bato mosusu bakotaka mingi te na esika ya mosala, mpe kotya bilembo ya kosokola maboko mpe bibongiseli mosusu ya komibatela na COVID-19. Na kotalela mosala bazosala, bato ya mosala oyo baza na likama ya katikati basengeli kolata bilamba na bango ya komibatela na ndakisa bagan, blouse, masque ya elongi, to maneti ya komibatela.
en-mt: It applies to professionals who encounter a wide variety of people such as in schools, in a very busy workplace, and in other public places. Maintaining machines for such people requires installing strong air filters, turning fans strong, installing separators such as itche air barriers, and installing window dressings for customer receptionists. Official protection for high-risk groups will require encouraging sick workers to stay at home, holding meetings online instead of in one place, setting rules to eliminate unnecessary travel to COVID-19 areas, developing strategies communication including forums to monitor workforce problems, provide workers with updates and appropriate training on COVID-19 risks and protective measures, provide training to workers who need to use clothing of self-care and instruction, providing equipment and working in a clean environment, requiring frequent hand washing, limiting access to the workplace by customers and others, and installing hand washing signs and facilities another way to protect yourself from COVID-1 Depending on the job they are doing, workers at moderate risk should wear their protective clothing such as gloves, blouses, face masks, or protective goggles.

sourceString: Workers in this risk group rarely require use of respirators.
targetString: Bato ya mosala oyo baza na etuluku oyo, esengaka mpenza te basalela biloko esalisaka na kopema.
en-mt: Workers in this group do not necessarily need to use respirators.

sourceString: If a person becomes sick on an airplane, proper controls to protect workers and other passengers include separating the sick person from others by a distance of 6 feet, designating one crew member to serve the sick person, and offering a face mask to the sick person or asking the sick person to cover their mouth and nose with tissues when coughing or sneezing.
targetString: Soki moto moko abeli na avion, lolenge ya malamu ya kobatela bato ya mosala mpe bato mosusu ezali kokabola ye na bato mosusu na distance ya 6 pied, kopona moto moko ya equipage mpo akipe moto wana ya maladi, mpe kopesa masque ya elongi to kosenga moto wana ya maladi azipa monoko na zolo na ye na elamba ntango azokosola to azosala itche.
en-mt: If someone falls ill on an airplane, the best way to protect crew and others is to isolate them from others at a distance of 6 feet, designate one crewmember to care for that sick person, and provide a face mask or ask for someone the patient should cover his mouth and nose with a cloth when sneezing or itching.

sourceString: Cabin crew should wear disposable medical gloves when tending to a sick traveler or touching body fluids or potentially contaminated surfaces, and possibly additional personal protective equipment if the sick traveler has fever, persistent cough, or difficulty breathing.
targetString: Bato ya mosala oyo baza na cabine basengeli kolata bagan ntango bazosalisa moto azosala mobembo oyo azobela to kosimba mai ya nzoto to esika nyonso oyo ekoki kopesa bango maladi, mpe komibatela mingi lisusu soki moto yango ya maladi azobela fievre, kosukosu oyo ezosila te, to azopema na mpasi.
en-mt: Cabin crew should wear gloves when treating a sick passenger or touching body fluids or any potentially infectious surface, and take extra precautions if the patient has a fever, persistent cough, or wheezing with difficulty.

sourceString: Gloves and other disposable items should be disposed of in a biohazard bag, and contaminated surfaces should be cleaned and disinfected afterwards.For commercial shipping, including cruise ships and other passenger vessels, hazard controls include postponing travel when sick, and self-isolating and informing the onboard medical center immediately if one develops a fever or other symptoms while on board.
targetString: Bagan mpe biloko mosusu oyo babwaka nsima ya kosalela esengeli kobwakama na esika ebongi, mpe bosengeli kopetola mpe kolongola mikrobe na bisika oyo ezwi mikrobe. Mpo na maswa ya mombongo, ata mpe bato de croisière mpe bato mosusu oyo baza nakati, komibatela elimboli koboya kosala mobembo soki ozobela, mpe komifandela mpe koyebisa minganga oyo baza nakati mbala moko soki moto moko oyo aza na kati aza na fievre to bilembo ya maladi mosusu.
en-mt: Bagan and other post-use waste should be disposed of properly, and contaminated areas should be cleaned and disinfected. For merchant ships, including cruise ships and other passengers, self-care means refraining from traveling if you are sick, and staying safe and notifying the doctors on board immediately if anyone on board has a fever or symptoms some.

sourceString: Ideally, medical follow-up should occur in the isolated person's cabin.For schools and childcare facilities, CDC recommends short-term closure to clean or disinfect if an infected person has been in a school building regardless of community spread.
targetString: Eza malamu kolandela santé ya moto wana ya maladi na esika oyo batye ye. Mpo na biteyelo to bisika ya kobatela bana, CDC ezosenga kokanga esika wana na ntango moke mpo na kopetola to kolongola mikrobe soki moto moko ya maladi azalaki na lopango ya eteyelo ezala maladi epanzani mingi to te esika bofandi.
en-mt: It is good to monitor the health of the patient in the placement. For schools or child care centers, the CDC will require a temporary closure of the facility for cleaning or disinfection if a sick person was on school grounds whether or not the disease is widespread where you live.

sourceString: When there is minimal to moderate community transmission, social distancing strategies can be implemented such as canceling field trips, assemblies, and other large gatherings such as physical education or choir classes or meals in a cafeteria, increasing the space between desks, staggering arrival and dismissal times, limiting nonessential visitors, and using a separate health office location for children with flu-like symptoms.
targetString: Soki bokono ezopanza mingi mpenza te na kati ya bato, bokoki kosalela mayele ya kopekisa bato bakutana na ndakisa kopekisa mibembo, mayangani, mpe makita mosusu ya minene na ndakisa education physique to korale na biteyelo to kolya na restaurant, ata mpe distance ezokabola babiro, kozelazela na ntango ya koya to ya kokende, koboya bavisite ezangi ntina, mpe kosalela babiro ya minganga ekeseni mpo na bana oyo bazali na bilembo ya grippe.
en-mt: If the disease is not very widespread, you can use contact prevention measures such as banning travel, conventions, and other large gatherings such as physical education or choir in schools or restaurant meals, even distance separating offices, waiting during arrival or departure, avoiding unnecessary visits, and using separate medical offices for children with flu symptoms.

sourceString: When there is substantial transmission in the local community, in addition to social distancing strategies, extended school dismissals may be considered.For law enforcement personnel performing daily routine activities, the immediate health risk is considered low by CDC.
targetString: Soki maladi epanzani mingi esika bofandi, longola mayele ya koyebisa bato bamifandela, bokoki kokanga biteyelo mpo na ntango ya mwa molai. Mpo na bapolisi oyo bazosala mosala na bango bo momeseno, CDC elobi ete likama na bango eza na nivo ya se.
en-mt: If the disease is widespread in your area, in addition to evacuation measures, you may be able to close schools for a longer period of time. For routine police officers, the CDC says their risk is at a lower level.

sourceString: Law enforcement officials who must make contact with individuals confirmed or suspected to have COVID-19 are recommended to follow the same guidelines as emergency medical technicians, including proper personal protective equipment.
targetString: Bakonzi ya bapolisi oyo basengeli kokutana na bato oyo baza na COVID-19 to oyo bakoki kozala na yango, esengeli batosa mibeko ya ndenge moko na oyo minganga batosaka, ata mpe kolata bisaleli malamu mpo na komibatela.
en-mt: Police officers who have to deal with people who have or may have COVID-19 should follow the same rules as doctors, including wearing proper protective equipment.

sourceString: If close contact occurs during apprehension, workers should clean and disinfect their duty belt and gear prior to reuse using a household cleaning spray or wipe, and follow standard operating procedures for the containment and disposal of used PPE and for containing and laundering clothes.
targetString: Soki bosimba moto ntango bozokanga ye, bato wana basengeli kopetola mpe kolongola mikrobe na nkamba na bango ya mosala mpe na bisaleli na bango liboso ya kosalela yango, bakosala yango na lisalisi ya aspirateur mpe kolanda mibeko etali komibatela mpe kobwaka biloko oyo PPE epesi mpe ya kobatela mpe kosokola bilamba.
en-mt: If you touch someone while holding them, they should clean and disinfect their work clothes and equipment before use, using a vacuum cleaner and following the precautions and disposal of PPE and safety equipment and washing clothes.

sourceString: OSHA considers certain healthcare and mortuary workers to be at high or very high categories of exposure risk.
targetString: OSHA etalelaka bato mosusu oyo basalaka mosala ya monganga mpe oyo basalaka na morgue ete baza na likama makasi to baza na kati ya bato oyo baza na likama makasi.
en-mt: OSHA considers certain medical and mortuary personnel to be high-risk or in the high-risk category.

sourceString: High exposure risk jobs include healthcare delivery, support, laboratory, and medical transport workers who are exposed to known or suspected COVID-19 patients.
targetString: Misala ya likama makasi eza na ndakisa kobotisa, kosalisa, laboratoire, mpe bato oyo bamema bato ya maladi oyo baza na COVID-19 to bakoki kozala na yango.
en-mt: High-risk occupations include maternity, treatment, laboratory, and transportation of patients who have or may have COVID-1

sourceString: These become very high exposure risk if workers perform aerosol-generating procedures on, or collect or handle specimens from, known or suspected COVID-19 patients.
targetString: Bakomaka na likama makasi soki bazosala misala ya aerosol, to bazozwa to bazosalela ba échantillon euti na bato oyo baza na COVID-19 to bakoki kozala na yango.
en-mt: They become at greater risk if they engage in aerosol activities, or collect or use samples from people who have or may have COVID-1

sourceString: Aerosol-generating procedures include intubation, cough induction procedures, bronchoscopies, some dental procedures and exams, or invasive specimen collection.
targetString: Misala ya aerosol eza misala neti intubation, kosalisa kosukosu, bronchoscopie, to misala to ba ekzame mosusu ya mino, to kozwa ba écahntillon.
en-mt: Aerosol services include services such as intubation, cough treatment, bronchoscopy, or other dental procedures or examinations, or taking specimens.

sourceString: High exposure risk mortuary jobs include workers involved in preparing the bodies of people who had known or suspected cases of COVID-19 at the time of their death; these become very high exposure risk if they perform an autopsy.Additional engineering controls for these risk groups include isolation rooms for patients with known or suspected COVID-19, including when aerosol-generating procedures are performed.
targetString: Likama makasi ya misala ya morgue etali bato oyo basalaka mosala ya kobongisa bibembe ya bato oyo bakufaki na COVID-19 na ntango bakufi to oyo bato oyo bakanisi ete bazalaki na yango; bazalaka na likama makasi soki basali ekzame na nsima mpo na koyeba soki bakufaki na maladi nini. Likama mosusu mpo na bango eza soki bazosalisa bato oyo baza na COVID-19 to oyo bakanisi baza na yango na bashambre na bango, ata mpe ntango bazosala misala ya aerosol.
en-mt: The high risk of mortuary operations involves persons engaged in preparing the bodies of persons who have died of COVID-19 at the time of their deaths or who are suspected to have been in contact with them; they are at higher risk if they are later tested for cause of death. Another risk for them is if they are treating people with or suspected of having COVID-19 in their rooms, even when doing aerosol activities.

sourceString: Specialized negative pressure ventilation may be appropriate in some healthcare and mortuary settings.
targetString: Kotinda mwa mopepe ya ventilateur ekoki kozala malamu na balopitalo mosusu mpe na ba morgue.
en-mt: Sending some ventilator air may be appropriate in some hospitals and mortuaries.

sourceString: Specimens should be handled with Biosafety Level 3 precautions.
targetString: Esengeli kosalela ba échantillon na kolanda nivo ya libateli ya bio 3.
en-mt: Samples must be handled in accordance with the bio 3 safety level.

sourceString: The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends that incoming patients be separated into distinct waiting areas depending on whether they are a suspected COVID-19 case.In addition to other PPE, OSHA recommends respirators for those who work within 6 feet of patients known to be, or suspected of being, infected with SARS-CoV-2, and those performing aerosol-generating procedures.
targetString: Organisation mondiale de la santé (OMS) elobi ete eza malamu kokabola bato ya maladi na bisika ya kozela ekeseni na kotalela soki bozokanisa baza na maladi ya COVID-19 to te. Longola likanisi ya kosala biloko esalisaka na kopema oyo PPE, OSHA elobeli mpo na bato oyo bazosala na distance ya 6 pied na bato oyo bayebani baza na SARS-CoV-2, oyo bozokanisa baza na yango, to oyo bazwi yango, mpe kosala misala mosusu ya aerosol.
en-mt: The World Health Organization (WHO) says it is best to separate patients in different waiting areas based on whether they are suspected of having COVID-19 or not. In addition to the concept of respiratory aids that PPE, OSHA mentions for people working within 6 feet of people who are known to have SARS-CoV-2, who you suspect have, or have been infected, and perform other tasks of aerosol.

sourceString: In the United States, NIOSH-approved N95 filtering facepiece respirators or better must be used in the context of a comprehensive, written respiratory protection program that includes fit-testing, training, and medical exams.
targetString: Na États-Unis, biloko esalisaka na kopema N95 oyo endimami na NIOSH to ya malamu koleka esengeli kosalelama mingi na makambo ya komibatela na maladi ya mpema na ndakisa test ya ajustement, formation, mpe ba-ekzame ya monganga.
en-mt: In the United States, N95 respirators approved by NIOSH or better should be widely used in respiratory prevention situations such as adjustment testing, training, and clinical examinations.

sourceString: Other types of respirators can provide greater protection and improve worker comfort.The WHO does not recommend coveralls, as COVID-19 is a respiratory disease rather than being transmitted through bodily fluids.
targetString: Lolenge mosusu ya biloko esalisaka na kopema ebatelaka mingi mpe esalisaka bato basala malamu. OMS endimaka te biloko ezipaka elongi mobimba, mpo COVID-19 eza maladi ya mpema mpe epanzanaka te na nzela ya mai ya nzoto.
en-mt: Other types of respirators are more protective and improve performance. The WHO does not approve of full face masks, because COVID-19 is a respiratory disease and is not spread through body fluids.

sourceString: WHO recommends only a surgical mask for point-of-entry screening personnel.
targetString: OMS ezosenga kaka kosalela masque ya minganga mpo bato oyo bazosalisa ba ekzame.
en-mt: The WHO still requires the use of medical masks for people undergoing tests.

sourceString: For those who are collecting respiratory specimens from, caring for, or transporting COVID-19 patients without any aerosol-generating procedures, WHO recommends a surgical mask, goggles, or face shield, gown, and gloves.
targetString: Mpo na bato oyo bazozwa ba échantilllon ya maladi ya mpema na bato ya maladi, kobatela bango, to komema bato oyo bazobela COVID-19 kozanga kosala misala ya aerosol, OMS ezondima kosalela masque ya minganga, maneti ya libateli, to eloko ya kobatela elongi, blouse, mpe bagan.
en-mt: For persons collecting respiratory samples from patients, caring for, or transporting persons with COVID-19 without aerosol procedures, WHO recommends the use of a medical mask, protective goggles, or face shield, blouse, and bagan.

sourceString: If an aerosol-generating procedure is performed, the surgical mask is replaced with an N95 or FFP2 respirator.
targetString: Soki bosali misala ya aerosol, na esika ya masque ya minganga, bokosalela eloko esalisaka na kopema N95 to FFP2.
en-mt: If you perform aerosol tasks, instead of a medical mask, you will use an N95 or FFP2 respirator.

sourceString: Given that the global supply of PPE is insufficient, WHO recommends minimizing the need for PPE through telemedicine, physical barriers such as clear windows, allowing only those involved in direct care to enter a room with a COVID-19 patient, using only the PPE necessary for the specific task, continuing use of the same respirator without removing it while caring for multiple patients with the same diagnosis, monitoring and coordinating the PPE supply chain, and discouraging the use of masks for asymptomatic individuals.
targetString: Mpo biloko nyonso oyo PPE ezopesa ekoki te, OMS azondima kosalela mingi te PPE na telemedecine, bipekiseli mpo bato bakutana te na ndakisa bafenetre ya polele, kopesa nzela na minganga na kokota na shambre ya moto oyo azobela COVID-19, kosalela kaka PPE oyo eza ntina mpo na mosala ya sikisiki, kokoba kosalela eloko kaka moko esalisaka na kopema kozanga kolongola yango ntango azosalisa bato mingi oyo bazobela maladi moko, kobatela mpe kosalela malamu ba PPE mosusu, mpe kolendisa te kosalela bamasque mpo na bato oyo baza na bilembo te.
en-mt: Because of the insufficient availability of PPE, WHO will accept limited use of PPE in telemedicine, restrictions on contact such as open windows, allowing doctors to enter the room of a COVID-19 patient, using only available PPE important for specific work, continue to use the same respiratory aid without removing it when treating multiple patients, maintain and use other PPE properly, and do not encourage the use of masks for people without symptoms.

targetString: EUTI NA: Katherine Maher, CEO ya fondation Wikimedia
en-mt: FROM: Katherine Maher, CEO of the Wikimedia foundation

targetString: NA: Basali nyonso ya fondation Wikimedia
en-mt: TO: All Wikimedia foundation staff

en-mt: MAN OF THE CASE: [Covid-19] Lighting the way and preparing for the future

en-mt: DATE/TIME SENT: March 14, 2020, 00:24 UTC
